item.description: Britain is headed for a series of clashes with Brussels over Brexit
item.body: Britain is heading for a series of clashes with Brussels, after ministers from the 27 remaining member states agreed proposals which would require the UK to obey the EU rule-book in full for around two years after Brexit. Downing Street acknowledged there were "differences" between London and Brussels over the nature of the "transition period" following the official date of Brexit in March 2019. And horrified Brexiteers urged Theresa May to reject the "ultimatum" set out in the negotiating mandate detailing the deal chief EU negotiator Michel Barnier will seek in talks expected to last until March. The document, agreed in a meeting lasting just two minutes in Brussels, includes proposals for:. - A transition period of 21 months, ending on December 31 2020, rather than the "implementation period" of around two years favoured by Mrs May;. - The cut-off date for EU citizens to enjoy full rights in the UK to be the end of the transition in December 2020, rather than March 2019 as suggested in the agreement on phase one of the Brexit talks last month;. - Britain to be required to obey all existing EU rules and regulations - including free movement of people - during transition, as well as any new laws agreed by the 27 after the UK has been removed from decision-making bodies;. - The UK to continue to comply with EU trade policy until the end of transition, meaning it cannot implement new trade deals. Speaking in Brussels, Mr Barnier insisted the UK could not pick and choose the rules it will follow. "During transition the UK will continue to take part in the single market, to take part in the customs union," he said. "It will continue to have all the economic benefits, therefore it must also apply all the EU rules. The single market cannot be a la carte." Downing Street said the new guidelines were "well aligned" with the UK position set out by Mrs May in her speech in Florence last year, though her official spokesman added: "There will naturally be some distance in the detail of our starting positions." Brexit Secretary David Davis predicted bust-ups over several aspects of the EU's stance. "There will be an argument about the right to negotiate free trade agreements," he told the House of Lords EU Committee. "There will be an argument, I'm sure, about the issue of whether or not we can object to new laws that we haven't had a say in. "There will be discussions about issues like representation on technical committee." Mr Davis also suggested that final agreement on the withdrawal deal may continue as late as the end of 2018 in order to allow more time to "iron out" details of the future UK/EU trade relationship. But Mr Barnier gave short shrift to the idea, saying the October deadline for the deal could not change by more than a week or so because time had to be allowed for ratification. In the House of Commons, Tory eurosceptic Sir Bill Cash urged the Government to reject any agreement which requires the UK to remain a part of EU frameworks after the date of Brexit. "Given that we're leaving the EU and therefore the customs union, the single market and the provisions relating to freedom of movement, is the Government going to reject this new EU ultimatum - including that the EU court of justice will continue to apply to the UK?" he asked. And former minister John Redwood said Britain must be prepared to walk away without a deal. "Many of us want new borders, fishing and agriculture policies and the reduction of taxes the EU insists on where we do not agree," said Mr Redwood. "To get on with improving these we do not want a two-year so-called transitional period if that means we can't take control of our laws, borders and money." As Mrs May met her Brexit "inner circle" for a meeting in Downing Street, the chairman of the Commons Exiting the EU Committee, Hilary Benn, was scathing about ministers' failure to provide a clear vision of the post-withdrawal end-state which they are seeking. "We are now 19 months on from the referendum and neither Parliament nor the rest of EU are any the wiser about what the Government actually wants from the Brexit negotiations," said Mr Benn. "Extraordinary and unacceptable." Downing Street declined to comment on reports that German Chancellor Angela Merkel had told reporters in a private meeting that whenever she asks Mrs May what she is seeking, the Prime Minister responds: "Make me an offer." Brexit legislation will go before the House of Lords on Tuesday where it is set for a rocky ride. Sir Vince Cable said he believes the Liberal Democrats can win enough support to get at least 10 amendments through, including junking the exit day from the legislation through an "unholy alliance". A map showing the at-risk areas for high tides. January 31 2018 Photo: Environment Agency
item.title: Britain told it must follow EU rules during 21-month transition after Brexit  - The Mail

item.description: ROTHERHAM United kick off the new Championship season away to Brentford.
item.body: ROTHERHAM United kick off the new Championship season away to Brentford. Paul Warne will take his side to Griffin Park on Saturday, August 5, with the first home game against Paul Hurst's Ipswich Town a week later. Sheffield United visit the AESSEAL New York Stadium on Saturday, November 24 and the Millers visit Sheffield Wednesday on Saturday, December 8. The Owls come to the NYS on Saturday, February 16 with the second match against the Blades at Bramall Lane on Saturday, March 9. The Boxing Day fixture is at Bolton while Preston visit on New Year's Day.

item.description: Virgin Trains is awarded West Coast franchise
item.body: Labour former transport secretary Lord Adonis has accused Chris Grayling of "another unjustified bailout" of Virgin and Stagecoach over the East Coast mainline franchise. Virgin has been awarded the new West Coast franchise and Lord Adonis said this was "without any competition whatsoever" and Stagecoach was being allowed to bid for further franchises "despite walking away from the East Coast mainline". Lord Adonis claimed the Transport Secretary's actions were "costing the taxpayer very dearly" after peers heard a Government statement on the contract for running the East Coast franchise ending earlier than expected. He told the Lords Mr Grayling was "undertaking another unjustified bailout of Virgin and Stagecoach at the expense of taxpayers". Lord Adonis said: "The reason for these disgraceful bailouts we've been seeing from Mr Grayling is because he simply is not prepared to contemplate putting his duty above ideology and substituting for failing private companies a state company. "He wants to make a whole set of cheap points about private good and public bad, which demean his office and are costing the taxpayer very dearly." Transport minister Baroness Sugg, who had repeated the Government's statement in the Lords, dismissed Lord Adonis' accusations, saying: "I'm afraid we don't recognise the bailout accusation." "Stagecoach will be held to all their contractual obligations in full," she added, and it would lose nearly £200 million under the change. Lady Sugg acknowledged the West Coast franchise was a "direct award" and no other bidder was involved. She said the privatisation process had brought benefits to rail users through investment in new trains, and highlighted customer satisfaction with services on the East Coast route. Virgin Trains issued a statement about the West Coast Mainline. it said: "Virgin Trains customers on the West Coast will see a significant improvement in on-board WiFi later this year. "All 56 Pendolino trains will undergo a refit which will vastly improve the on-board equipment, and allow free WiFi to be extended to all Pendolino customers. "The £7.5 million investment is part of a new deal agreed with the Government, which will see Virgin Trains continue to run the West Coast franchise through to at least March 31 2019, with the option for up to a further one-year extension at the Department for Transport's discretion. "The existing franchise expires on March 31 2018, and the new contract will bridge the gap between the existing franchise and the new West Coast Partnership, due to start on April 1 2019. "Installation of the WiFi upgrade is planned to begin on the Pendolino fleet from May 2018, with the work expected to be completed by January 2019, when free WiFi will be extended to all Pendolino customers. More than 85 per cent of our customers travel on Pendolinos. In addition, the new technology is 'future-proofed' so it will work with 5G mobile phone networks as they come on stream and offer further speed improvements. "The upgrade will also unlock the ability to offer more technology-led improvements in the future, all of which will increase customer satisfaction."
item.title: Transport Secretary Chris Grayling accused of 'another unjustified bailout'  - The Mail

item.description: The Voice UK is returning to Norwich to find singing superstars to take part in the next series.
item.body: Producers for the show will be in the city on Friday, April 20 between 12pm and 2pm. Auditions will take place at the Birdcage on Pottergate in the Norwich Lanes. A promotional poster for the audition says: “Do you think you’ve got what it takes to turn a chair?. “We are on the lookout for incredible singing solo artists and duos for The Voice 2019.” Those wanting to audition are asked to prepare one song acapella or with a backing track. Backing tracks must be provided by the singer and will need to be on an electronic device. Auditions are also being held at 3.30pm on April 19 at The Garage on Chapelfield North. • You must be 16 age or over by October 1 2018 to audition and to book a slot email bookings@thebirdcagenorwich.co.uk
item.title: The Voice UK to hold more open auditions in Norwich at The Birdcage - Latest Norfolk and Suffolk News

item.description: After months of anticipation, a first look at the upcoming movie Fighting With My Family about a wrestler from Norfolk has been revealed.
item.body: The film by Dwayne “The Rock” Johnson and Stephen Merchant follows the Knight family of wrestlers from Norwich and their daughter Paige’s journey to become a WWE champion. A never-before-seen clip from the movie, lasting one minute and 56 seconds, was released on Saturday, April 7 and features Florence Pugh as Paige and Jack Lowden as her brother Zak, backstage at WWE try outs. READ MORE: The Rock reveals plans to make “gritty” film about Norwich wrestling familyDuring the scene the pair bump into wrestling legend The Rock and ask him for advice on winning over the crowd. Paige introduced the exclusive footage on Saturday at the NXT TakeOver: New Orleans show. She said: “Paige here and I’m extremely excited to show you a sneak peek of the new movie based on my life called Fighting With My Family. READ MORE: The Rock’s Fighting With My Family takes over Gentleman’s Walk as filming gets underway in Norwich“This scene where my brother and I are backstage at WWE for the very first time features some incredible actors playing us and some guy in a hoodie you might have heard of.” Also starring Lena Headey, Nick Frost and Vince Vaughn, scenes for the movie were filmed on location in Norwich and Great Yarmouth in April 2017. READ MORE: Lena Headey and more tweet the Norwich wrestlers they’ll be playing in new filmFighting With My Family is set to be released in the UK on September 28 2018.
item.title: WWE release sneak peek of The Rock's upcoming Fighting With My Family film about Norwich wrestler Paige - Latest Norfolk and Suffolk News

item.description: Rail commuters will be breathing a sigh of relief after it was announced a full train service on the Great Eastern Main Line will resume from Monday following a week of disruption.
item.body: Email this article to a friend. To send a link to this page you must be logged in. Engineers are scheduled to install a new piece of track overnight this weekend after a crack was discovered on the approach to Liverpool Street station last Sunday. Two platforms at the London station were forced to close and this affected a number of peak Greater Anglia services to and from the capital. The section of track is specially made to fit a curve on the approach to Liverpool Street and Network Rail said the crack was too big to repair – meaning a replacement part was required. Passengers took to social media to make their feelings known about the delays and cancellations to services. Steve Hooker, Network Rail’s head of maintenance for Anglia, said: “I understand that some passengers will have had some difficult journeys over the last few days and I’d like to apologise to those who have been affected. “We have worked as quickly as possible to build a new piece of track so that services can return to normal. I’d like to thank passengers for their patience during this time.” Jamie Burles, Greater Anglia managing director, thanked passengers who have been affected during the week. “I’d like to thank our customers for their patience this week,” he said. “We have been trying hard to make sure that all customers have been able to get to their destination by train, but we’re sorry that trains were fuller than usual and that there were some delays and cancellations. “Liverpool Street is such a busy station, it’s not possible to run all trains in the rush hour as normal when two platforms are closed. “We drafted in extra help at affected stations to help customers catch their right train to try to make things a little easier for customers.” Saturday services will run as scheduled but there may be some changes to morning services on Sunday. Passengers are asked to check before travelling via www.greateranglia.co.uk, the Greater Anglia app, @greateranglia on Twitter, or www.nationalrail.co.uk
item.title: Relief for rail commuters as full train service to Liverpool Street set to resume from Monday - Stowmarket News

item.body:
The friends of a West Belfast footballer who died suddenly have designed a special T-shirt to be worn at his funeral. 
 
Eamon O'Connor, 18, passed away in the early hours of Monday.
 
In a statement to Belfast Live, the club, where he played from the age of 10 until recently, paid tribute.
 
They said: "Eamon was a brilliant young footballer from he joined us at around ten years old.
 
"He was an excellent teammate, and would back his team up in every situation.
 
 
"His football ability was impeccable, and it was often that Eamon took control of a game.
 
 Eamon O’Connor death - tributes paid to popular young West Belfast footballer 
 
"Every individual who was lucky enough to have met him will remember his big smile, crazy antics and his huge personality that would light up a room.
 
"Eamon was a gentleman, and a true leader on and off the pitch.
 
"We'll never forget Eamon and the memories we shared with him, nor will we forget his own catchphrases, like how he would greet everyone with the word “Dawg!”. RIP Eamon."
 
 You can get the T-shirts from Kolormaster, on the Falls Road , at a cost of £6. They will be printed while you wait. 
 
Eamon’s funeral is to take place on Saturday in Corpus Christi Parish at 9.30am.
 
 
   Anyone who needs to talk to someone about mental health issues can call the Samaritans on 116123.   
 
  Irish tourist dies after balcony fall in Spain

item.body:
Liverpool is set to welcome a brand new cinema next month, but before it opens its doors to the public, the ECHO was given a behind the scenes tour.
 
Cineworld is opening at Speke's New Mersey Retail Park on Friday, August 10 with huge anticipation surrounding this new developement.
 
Plans to bring a cinema to the area were announced more than two years ago along with a number of new restaurants including Nandos and Wagamamas which opened last month.
 
 
Staff including General Manager Andy Starkie today revealed the 11-screen cinema will also be home to a Starbucks on the ground floor as well as a super-screen which will be one of the biggest available in Merseyside.
 
 
The Starbucks will have both indoor and outdoor seating as well as a terrace which will be based on the dome side.
 
 
All seats will be premium red leather and will have the option to recline.
 
 
The cinema will be completely paperless too, with digital ordering screens for tickets.
 
We'll be bringing you all the latest updates ahead of this opening, so make sure you check back for updates.
 
New Mersey Retail Park

item.body:
Hector Bellerin doesn't fit the stereotype of your average footballer.
 
At 23-years-old, he's already left Barcelona's legendary La Masia academy for the chance of a pathway through to first team football at Arsenal, purchased an eco-friendly Tesla car and is heavily into his fashion.
 
It seems to have so far worked for the Spaniard - despite being snubbed for the World Cup in Russia this summer, Bellerin has be labelled as five of the 'untouchables' by new boss Unai Emery, alongside Alexandre Lacazette, Granit Xhaka, Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang and Henrikh Mkhitaryan in the Arsenal squad.
 
He's also one of the highest regarded full backs in the Premier League, and it all stems back to a decision as a 16-year-old to leave the familiar surroundings of La Masia and sign for Arsenal.
 
Sokratis, Torreira, Ramsey - Predicted Arsenal starting XI for Manchester City opener
 
Some might call it tough, but as Bellerin himself explains, he likes challenges.
 
Speaking to Wealthsimple’s Money Diaries, he said: "When footballers in Europe turn 16, they can sign working contracts, which means they can go abroad. I was playing with FC Barcelona's youth academy, La Masia, and when I turned 16, I thought I would stay with Barca.
 
"But I wasn't feeling like they were showing me on paper what they were saying — let’s put it that way. I'm not talking just financially, but also in terms of my path into the first team.
 
 
 
 
"Halfway through that year, I got the call that Arsenal were interested in me. So, I went to London, saw the facilities, met with the boss, and they made me an offer.
 
"Everything looked so great, and my path into the first team was clear — obviously as long as I worked hard and I was reaching my targets. I like challenges and adventures.
 
"Even though people might have thought I was putting myself in a tough position by leaving my country and my family, it was actually quite easy, and exciting.
 
 
 
 
Money is a big subject for top flight footballers - everyone has an opinion on the amount stars are paid for plying their trade in the Premier League.
 
But for Bellerin, his upbringing as young boy in Spain with his grandmother has had an effect on how he views the vast sums he gets paid as a footballer and has taught him the value of the money that comes into his bank account every month.
 
There's no wonder why the 23-year-old is so into fashion, it's been ingrained him from an early age when his grandmother would pay him £2 to clean her factory.
 
'A big few weeks' -Jack Wilshere provides update on his future after leaving Arsenal
 
"I don’t actually know the most expensive thing I’ve ever bought., he added, "it would probably be a jacket, because I don't really spend that much on any other things. Loads of players love cars. Loads of players love the stock markets.
 
"For me, it's fashion. My mom and grandma have made clothes their whole life.
 
"My grandma had her own factory. When there was no kids to play football with in my local park, I would go to my grandma's factory. She used to give me £2 if I cleaned all the threads and scraps off the floor. I even learned how to sew."
 
 
 
 
Football is a short career and for some, it comes to an end all too soon.
 
Despite the money and the glamour, once a player's career comes to an end there's a big wide world out there that very little have explored in terms of career avenues, with most only knowing football.
 
It's a concern - some players leave it late to start planning for life after football, but Bellerin isn't like those stars, showing remarkable maturity for someone as young as 23.
 
England & Man City star Raheem Sterling reveals why he chose to join QPR over Arsenal
 
Instead, his ambition is to make sure he gets to a stage in his career where he can play football without having to think about the money that comes with it, and the road to that has started already as Bellerin has began planning for his life in the future.
 
"What I'm making sure is that I have something for life after. My goal is to get to a point where I can play football without having to think about how much I'm getting paid — a point in which the finance is not in my head anymore.
 
"Some players, when they get to age 27 or 28, all of a sudden they get this thought in their head like, "I don't know if I have that much time anymore, so I'm gonna have to start investing.”
 
 
 
 
"And sometimes they put so much risk into it that they end up losing money. I thought, instead of waiting so long, why don't I just start taking care and managing my money and getting ready for the future now?
 
"It might be 15 to 20 years away, but the sooner you do it, the more ready you are when it happens."
 
To read the full interview with Bellerin, visit: Wealthsimple’s Money Diaries
 
How Arsenal boss Unai Emery can help Mesut Ozil to realise his true potential this season

item.body:
While both Granit Xhaka's and Xherdan Shaqiri's celebrations may have seemed harmless at first glance - a passionate response in a famous Swiss World Cup victory - the real meaning lies deeper.
 
Switzerland's squad has a diverse make-up with a number of players holding dual nationality or having roots elsewhere.
 
Shaqiri for example wore boots donning both the Swiss and Kosovan flag. As he noted: "I was born in Kosovo, but I grew up in Switzerland. I live both mentalities, it's not a big difference."
 
However, such connotations are not quite as simple as that when you consider that Kosovo is not recognised as independent from Serbia by the nation, and the appearance of such a flag could be considered provocative.
 
Both Shaqiri - who speaks Albanian - and Xhaka formed their hands into what is generally considered to be an eagle - the symbol of Albanian flag.
 
 
Serbia 1-2 Switzerland player ratings - Xhaka strike inspires Swiss, dominant Mitrovic display
 
 
 
The Arsenal midfielder is the younger brother of Taulant Xhaka who plays for Albania and was actually born in Serbia to Albanian parents.
 
Serbia's relationship with Albania is problematic in itself and perhaps especially so for Xhaka.
 
In 2014 when Albanian Prime Minister Edi Rama met with Serbian Prime Minister Aleksandar Vucic in 2014, for the first meeting of it's sorts since 1947, tempers arose as the Albanian PM said that Kosovo's independence was 'undeniable' and was consequently accused of provocation.
 
With the undertone of angst between Albanian/Kosovan ancestry and Serbia, the relationship only becomes more poignant when you consider the midfielder's father spent three and half years imprisoned for taking part in demonstrations against Serbia's communist government during the 80s.
 
On Instagram Xhaka made the connection to his celebration very clear.
 
 
A second image said 'We did it bro' with an image of both Xhaka's and Shaqiri's celebration side by side.
 
The pair landed themselves in trouble for the celebrations due to the political connotations. After Serbia reported their actions an investigation found that they had infringed on rules and forced them to pay a fine.
 
'Why doesn't Xhaka do that for Arsenal?' - Gunners fans saying the same thing after wonder goal
 
FIFA rules state that players will be punished for such statements made in celebration.

item.description: A fundraising campaign set up by Norwich City supporters to help improve the atmosphere at Carrow Road has outstripped its £3,000 target just days after launching.
item.body: The Barclay End Norwich supporters group and fansite Along Come Norwich have launched a crowdfunder campaign to help with their efforts to better project the passion of the Canaries’ faithful at home matches. The groups set a target to raise £3,000, to be used to buy flags, banners and displays for supporters to raise aloft in the Lower Barclay - and potentially the Upper Barclay too. They said clubs in Europe and, closer to home, those such as Nottingham Forest, Watford and Aston Villa had put on similar displays, with the goal of uniting fans, showing support for the Canaries’ players and intimidating the opposition team. And, in less than a week, they outstripped their target. They said they have already set about arranging things for the start of the season. Among the comments from those getting involved on the GoFundMe page were these:. Anthony Faiers said: “Great initiative here. I’ve got a season ticket back in the Barclay for the first time in years, having recently moved back from Dortmund. If there’s one club who know about creating a good atmosphere, it’s them and I fully support you trying to bring some of that to Carrow Road.” David Vickery wrote: “My seat is a long way from the Barclay, but I look forward to seeing the results of this initiative Well done for the positive attitude.” Andrew Rivett-Carnac said: “Excellent initiative. Deserves to be a storming success.” The crowdfunder, however, will stay open, with the organisers saying the more they raise, the more they will be able to do over the course of the season. Barclay End Norwich tweeted: “Thank you so much to everyone who has contributed. Football without fans is nothing, but neither are we.” The first 120 people who donate more than £10 will get a Barclay End Norwich pin badge, while One City Strong T-shirts are being sold, with all profits going into the crowdfunder.
item.title: Crowdfunder for better atmosphere at Norwich City's Carrow Road hits £3,000 goal - Latest Norfolk and Suffolk News

item.body:
Gardai in Dublin have launched an urgent public appeal as they seek assistance in tracing the whereabouts of 28 year-old Marcin Zielinski.
 
Marcin has been missing from his home at North Summer Street, Dublin 1, since the June 23 2018.
 
He is described as being 5 foot 7 inches in height, of stocky build and with a receding hairline.
 
However, they say they have received no details of what Marcin might have been wearing when he went missing last week.
 
Gardai are appealing for anyone with information that could lead to Marcin's whereabouts to contact Mountjoy Garda Station on 01 666 8600.

item.body:
The ash cloud caused by the Saddleworth Moor fire is so big it’s affecting local weather, experts have said. 
 
The heatwave continued on Wednesday with blazing sunshine and temperatures of 31 degrees in parts of Greater Manchester.
 
 But in Oldham it didn’t get higher than 26 degrees - and in areas immediately under the haze it barely crept above 23C. 
 
Meteorologists say this is down to the thick smoke blocking out the sun, which has burned a spectacular red during the evening in recent days.
 
Local weather expert Jon Bayliss, who tweets as @chadweather from Chadderton, told the M.E.N: “The UV here this morning was seven but the haze/smoke arrived and capped the temperature at 23C and dropped the UV to between 2 and 3.
 
 LIVE updates: Firefighters at Saddleworth Moor blaze call in the military to tackle 'biggest fire in living memory' 
 
“It’s cleared a bit now so temps up to 25C and UV levels have risen. Other areas without the haze have touched 28-29C.”
 
Alex Burkill, from the Met Office, agreed the smoke could be affecting weather.
 
 
“The fire has been big enough that there’s enough smoke to suppress temperatures a little bit,” he said. "Sunlight cannot get through and so there’s not as much heat.”
 
It’s is a similar effect as the cooling often experienced by places after a volcanic eruption.
 
When Indonesia’s Mount Tambora erupted for four months in 1815, experts believe the enormous ash cloud cooled the earth’s temperature by three degrees.
 
 The cause of the Saddleworth Moor fire is still unclear - but moorland managers are linking it to off-road bikers 
 
Across Europe, Asia and North America, 1816 became known as ‘the year without a summer’ after months of freezing rain and little sunlight.
 
FIREFIGHTERS CONTINUE TO BATTLE SADDLEWORTH MOOR WILDFIRE 
Nevertheless, more than 100 firefighters from Greater Manchester and Derbyshire have faced incredibly difficult conditions as they continue to battle the blaze which has now been burning for four days.
 
Around 34 homes in Calico Crescent, Stalybridge, were evacuated on Tuesday evening as the inferno was declared a ‘major incident’ by Greater Manchester Police.
 
Saddleworth moorland fire 
The fire service said that as of Wednesday, there were seven separate incidents ongoing on areas of the moors, including near Calico Crescent in Carrbrook, Intake Cottage, Intake Lane, Caste Farm, Dovestones, Higher Swineshaw and Chew Road.
 
The cause of the fire is still being investigated.

item.body:
With one pass, Ever Banega succeeded where a country had failed.
 
Lionel Messi, finally unleashed in the final third, struck home the goal that sent Argentina on their way into the knock out stages of the World Cup 2018.
 
It was the Barcelona forward's first strike from open play at the tournament, and one of the finest yet seen in Russia this summer - and it would not have been possible without Banega.
 
He got his first start against Nigeria, having been left on the bench for the loss to Croatia, and brought on as a sub in the draw to Iceland. While the debate rages on over who is in control of the dug out following stories of a player take over and Jorge Sampaoli's strange behaviour on the touch line, the identity of the decision maker is not important.
 
Nigeria 1-2 Argentina player ratings: Arsenal target Banega stars as Messi's side scrapes through
 
All that matters is that the call was made and Messi was finally allowed to play ahead of a footballer capable of thinking on his wavelength and delivering him some proper service from deep.
 
It has been a serious issue for the nine-time LaLiga champion at international level for many years. The last time he had a truly great playmaker to rely on to help him shoulder the creative burden of his national team was eight years ago when Juan Sebastian Veron was still on hand to take control in possession, albeit as he played on his last legs at the age of 35. Unfortunately for Messi, his manager that year was Diego Maradona.
 
While Argentina may have reached the final of the World Cup in Brazil four years ago, they did so almost wholly dependent on their super star, with Angel Di Maria supplying plenty of chaos and energy to try and distract opponents. It still all fell to Messi when a touch more craft was needed.
 
 
 
 
Banega has at last been allowed to fill that niche for Sampaoli and the change in flow, rythmn and fortune has already been obvious. Argentina looked a broken side with no hope of escaping the group stage. They now at least look akward to play against - a wounded animal with a puncher's chance if not a true contender.
 
Even Messi can't do it all by himself. No player can. Cristiano Ronaldo is making an impact in a Portugal team set up to allow him periods of rest in between his explosive moments. Messi has had to be everywhere for his side. Not anymore. Has Sven Mislintat been watching?
 
"Announce him now" - Arsenal fans go nuts for Ever Banega after majestic assist for Messi
 
Arsenal head coach Unai Emery will already know everything about Banega and his quality. He built his Sevilla side around the Argentinian having previously worked with him at Valencia, and it has been suggested that the Gunners are weighing up whether to sign the 29-year-old or opt for the gritty tenacity of Sampdoria's Lucas Torreira instead.
 
In truth, they should move for both players. For one, they offer completely different things. The Uruguayan is a feisty combatant who excels at winning the ball and closing opponents down. Banega is best in possession, threading the ball forward, picking gaps and hurting the opposition with the quality of his passing.
 
The transfer that could pave the way for Ever Banega to be reunited with Unai Emery at Arsenal
 
Emery has already had to wave goodbye to Santi Cazorla and Jack Wilshere is about to leave the Emirates. Granit Xhaka could do with some help in midfield, and Torreira looks to fit the bill as an enforcer capable of playing a bit too.
 
However, the Swiss is currently the only player who can relied upon to conduct the team from deep, and they lack a midfielder capable of filling the hole between the 25-year-old and Mesut Ozil in the middle of the field. Banega can play as the No. 10 behind the striker. He can also knit things together at the centre of the pitch, as he did for Argentina, and has done for other clubs on his CV, including Inter in Serie A.
 
 
 
 
Not only is he is talented, he can be a canny opponent too. Streetwise in how he draws fouls and uses his ability throw challenges off when he has the ball. Aaron Ramsey and Xhaka will not be able to play every minute of a campaign that will see the Gunners try to battle across all fronts, including the Europa League, for trophies and Champions League football.
 
He is good enough to start, of course, and depending on the opposition he would, but having options is still important. In tight games where Arsenal want a player with class to dictate moves in the final third, a more resilient alternative to Ozil would be very useful.
 
Against Nigeria, he ran the game, freeing up Messi to make the runs that were denied to him in the Croatia match when Sampaoli shackled him with too many responsibilities. While his touch and control for the goal was sublime, the pass to play him in was also a wonderful bit of football.
 
"Announce him now" - Arsenal fans go nuts for Ever Banega after majestic assist for Messi
 
Imagine what Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang could do with that service, or Henrikh Mkhitaryan scampering into the penalty box. The Armenian has already shown himself to be an excellent improviser in front of goal, especially when he was running onto the passes of Paul Pogba and others at Manchester United. His scorpion kick rivalled that of Olivier Giroud's own heel-struck effort.
 
What's more, Banega could be available for as little as €20million. That's the fee set by a release clause in his deal with Sevilla - although foreign clubs can have a hard time triggering these agreements as many Premier League clubs have found in recent years.
 
 
 
 
With his history of working well under Emery, and the clarity he can offer to teams on the pitch, the midfielder who liberated Lionel Messi against Nigeria is the closest thing to a dead cert that the Gunners are likely to come upon this summer.
 
Arsenal may have other plans in place. They have been linked with Aleksandr Golovin, Stanislav Lobotka and a raft of other playmakers and attacking midfielders.
 
However, Banega is one they cannot afford to dither over if he remains in the conversation among the Emirates hierarchy.
 
In one move, with one pass, he changed the course of a tournament for his country. A few hours later Ozil dropped out of the World Cup with Germany, unable to affect their destiny. 
 
Emery's Arsenal could do with a creator more capable of forcing their influence on the game in the moments that matter. Banega can be that player.
 
Why Lucas Vazquez is the final piece in the Arsenal jigsaw for Unai Emery and Sven Mislintat

item.body:
A dozen new Love Island contestants have been revealed ahead of tomorrow night's episode.
 
The 12 newbies are set to cause drama and heartache for the current islanders as they could be tempted to stray with the fresh meat.
 
The new female islanders are set to populate second villa Casa Amor, with the current boys sent in to meet the new ladies.
 
Meanwhile the original girls won't be lonely as the new boys are sent into the villa to keep them company.
 
Last year the boys trip to Casa Amor caused major .drama as both Kem and Marcel had their heads turned by the new girls.
 
Producers are hoping for the same explosive consequences this year, as the islanders fledging relationships are put to the test.
 
Here's everything you need to know about the new islanders.
 
The Girls 
Savanna Darnell 
 
  
Savanna is a 22-year-old dancer/singer from Sheffield.
 
Savanna is looking for a guy she can be herself around and wants to have an "amazing experience" in the villa.
 
No stranger to love Savanna has had three long term relationships, with her exes most likely to describe her as "expensive."
 
She said: "They say they end up spending a lot of money. But that’s them spending their money, I don’t ask them to! I’m considered quite unpredictable too. You don’t know from one day to the next what I’ll be like."
 
Grace Wardle 
 
  
Grace is a 25-year-old hairdresser from London.
 
The stylist is looking for long-term love in the villa, after only having one serious relationship.
 
She believes her eyes and her boobs are her best attributes, saying "Physically my eyes, and my breasts, as I paid for them so if they weren’t great I would be quite annoyed!"
 
Grace isn't afraid to create drama to get her man, but said she would talk things through with another girl, before going after their partner.
 
Charlie Williams 
 
  
Charlie is a 24-year-old tanning assistant from Bath.
 
Charlie describes what she wants from the villa as "in a nutshell I want someone nice, hard working and someone who wants to be in a genuine relationship."
 
And she's already got her eye on two of the boys saying: "I really like Alex –I like him more the more that I watch the show. His values are so strong. I think we’d have a lot in common. The new guy Sam also seems really funny; I think I would get on with him."
 
Kazimir Crossley 
 
  
Kazimir is a 23-year-old make-up artist from London.
 
Kazimir has done last year's winner Kem's make-up before and has been asking him for tips ahead of her entrance to the show.
 
Georgia best watch out as Kazimir has already set her eyes on Josh, saying: "I want to find an honest guy because I’ve come across so many liars. I like to be looked after. In the villa, I fancy Josh."
 
Adam's antics also failed to impress Kazimir, as she said: "What Adam did to Rosie puts me off, he gets what he wants and he needs to learn you can’t always get what you want."
 
Ellie Jones 
 
  
The 22-year-old admin assistant will be familiar to one islander - as she used to go out with Jack.
 
Speaking about their relationship she said: "I was seeing Jack Fincham on and off. We met in August 2016 and dated on and off for a while.
 
"We have always spoken because we got on so well. I actually spoke to him as a friend about two days before he went into the villa and had no idea he was going on the show!
 
"We weren’t in an official relationship but we spoke about it, would go on dates and kept trying to make it work but it wouldn’t.
 
"I met his brother and mates. I don’t know how he’ll feel when he sees me walk in.
 
"I don’t know if he’ll be angry or shocked but we do get on so hopefully it won’t be an issue. When I look at him, I do still think there is something there but I would never go back there."
 
While she might not be keen to rekindle things with Jack Ellie has got her eyes on another two islanders.
 
She said: "I fancy Josh. And I really fancy Alex because he’s so different to my normal type, I think I’m in love with him already and I’ve not even met him yet! He makes my heart melt, he’ll be a good person to bring home to my parents."
 
Darylle Sargeant 
 
  
Darylle is a 24-year-old eyebrow technician from Watford.
 
Darylle used to date Towie star Dean Ralph and says the pair have remained friends.
 
The tattoo loving babe is keen to find a kindred spirit in the villa and already knows who she wants, saying: "I like tall, dark and handsome! I am really tattooed so I love heavily tattooed guys but I also like people who have good chat and banter, someone who isn’t too serious.
 
"In the villa, I've got my eye on Adam, he is beautiful. I like Jack too and Josh."
 
 
 
Twitter reacts to the return of Love Island 2018 
 
 
Love Island 
 
 
The Boys 
Jordan Adefeyisan 
 
Jordan is a 23-year-old model from Stockport.
 
He describes his ideal girl as "A nice girl, with good banter and who I can click with properly. In the villa, I fancy Ellie, Megan and Georgia is fit as well. I know they are coupled up but it's all a game isn't it..."
 
Jordan has never had a serious relationship, but hates girls with attitude who think they are better than other people.
 
Charlie Brake 
 
Charlie is a 23-year-old socialite from Chelsea.
 
Charlie has already got his eye on Ellie and Megan in the villa and says he thinks people may be jealous of his family fortune.
 
He said: "I think a lot of people when they find out about my background, there might be a lot of jealousy there.
 
"My grandfather founded a food distribution company called Brakes which my family own and we sold it so everyone is well looked after.
 
"I visit my Dad in Monaco a lot and spend a lot of time in the French Alps."
 
Charlie has a Scouse ex, who will be surprised to see him on the show, as he explained: "I met another girl who was from Liverpool and ended up being with her for about a year and half and moved to America with her for a bit.
 
"Then it came to end. I reckon they’ll be surprised to see me on Love Island."
 
Frankie Foster 
 
  
Frankie is a 22-year-old business management student and fitness coach from Cheltenham.
 
Frankie used to play semi-professional rugby and says he's not the "stereotypical lad in skinny jeans and tight T shirts."
 
Ellie and Zara are the girls who have caught his attention as he described what he wants from the villa as: "I’d like to end up finding someone I really like. I change my mind in terms of who I like every time I watch it –but at the moment it is probably Ellie and Zara.
 
"They both seem cool and chatty. They’re most similar to my usual type."
 
Jack Fowler 
 
  
Jack in a 22-year-old semi-professional footballer from London.
 
Jack previously starred in a Tom Zanetti music video and is looking forward to his villa experience.
 
Keeping his cards close to his chest about his villa crush Jack said he was looking for a "brunette girl who is curvy with a nice bum and a nice smile and nice eyes. But we also need a connection."
 
Previously Jack has lied about his age to get a girl, he said: "I wanted to be with a girl who was a bit older than me so when I was 19, 20, I changed my age on Tinder to 25.
 
"I met a girl on there who was 24 and we had a date but when I got my wallet out to pay, she checked my ID and her face dropped when she saw I was younger than I’d said."
 
Alex Miller 
 
  
Alex is a 28-year-old structural glazier from Essex.
 
Alex describes himself as "pretty perfect" and says petite brunettes are his type.
 
He said: "In the villa I like Dani. I like Ellie too, she’s cute. Dani is very coupled up with Jack so we’ll have to see how coupled up they really are when I go in…"
 
Alex's advice to girls who want to woo him is: "Be bubbly, I don’t like boring birds. As long as they are funny and have a good personality. When it comes to my ideal date, I’ve got a great first date that I’ve done a few times – drinks in the city, onto a comedy show and then more drinks. I’ve got a good success ratio with that one!"
 
Dean Overson 
 
  
  
Dean is a 25-year-old car salesman from Burnley.
 
Newly single Dean is excited to have some fun in the villa and has his eye on several girls.
 
He said: "I like nice eyes and I want a girl to have a bit about them, someone you can speak to and who can hold a conversation.
 
"I like Megan and I’d go for Ellie. Zara is beautiful as well. I think all of the girls are lovely in their own way."
 
Dean's turn-offs are loud girls, as he said: "Someone who is very loud and a bit too much. And also if a girl thinks she is better than what she is. Like when you’re out and trying to speak to a girl and she is arrogant."
 
*Love Island continues on ITV2 at 9pm

item.body:
Campaigners are fighting for the future of a unique and troubled secondary school in Co Armagh. 
 
 They are calling on the Education Authority to preserve the Lurgan campus of Craigavon Senior High School, which is the only school in the UK that caters solely for GCSE students. 
 
Craigavon Senior High School was developed across two sites in Lurgan and Portadown as part of the pioneering Dickson Plan, which has offered a two-tier system of junior and senior high schools since the 1960s, effectively deferring selection to age 14.
 
 The senior school caters for 579 GCSE pupils, the majority of whom are on the Portadown site. 
 
The row began in 2016 when governors considered closing the Lurgan site after concerns were raised around health and safety, safeguarding and sustainability. They wanted to transport pupils by bus to the sister site in Portadown.
 
 1,000 people sign petition rejecting plans for four-schools amalgamation 
 
But the proposal was dropped following a backlash by parents who insisted their children continue their education in Lurgan.
 
Instead, they wanted the Education Authority to consider moving the children to temporary accommodation on the site of the junior school in Lurgan.
 
Parents claim the school has deteriorated due to a lack of investment by education officials amid continued uncertainty over its future.
 
They warn the current site is so "unfit for purpose" that children must "eat their lunch between parked cars" due to lack of outdoor space.
 
Comparing children in the small school yard to "caged animals at a zoo", they have called for the immediate resignation of the schools' governors who they accused of failing the children.
 
 Hundreds protest in Belfast at plans to merge special schools 
 
Community representative Norman Mawhinney said there was widespread concern about uncertainty over the school's future.
 
He added: "Our local sports clubs and politicians all agree with the need to keep these children in Lurgan.
 
"What we do not want is for them to continue to be educated in these awful conditions. People are prepared to fight for what they want for their children. We are stepping up our campaign by calling on governors to step aside."
 
 Belfast dad appeals for a potentially lifesaving donor for his seriously ill daughter 
 
MLA Doug Beattie claimed the issues affecting the senior Lurgan campus had been "obvious for 15 years".
 
He said: "The Lurgan campus was only supposed to be a temporary solution years ago when the Dickson plan was rolled out.
 
"It does not have playing fields, the pupils have to eat their lunches between parked cars and there are safeguarding concerns around its proximity to the Southern Regional College.
 
 Education chiefs warned to stop intruding on 'Catholic grammar schools' amid Co Down 'super school' plans 
 
"It is a sorry state of affairs. The problem is that instead of fixing the issues at the school, it has been allowed to run down."
 
He added: "Pupils cannot stay where they are because the school is not fit for purpose, but bussing them to Portadown is not the solution.
 
"Many of these children come from disadvantaged backgrounds and are the most vulnerable academically.
 
"There is a feeling that the Dickson Plan gives everything to the 60 per cent who are selected for grammar college and the rest are being neglected, it is truly awful."
 
 Smart hubs coming to Belfast city centre 
 
The principal of Craigavon Senior High School was unavailable for comment but an Education Authority spokesman said: “There is broad agreement across all stakeholders that short, medium and long-term action is required in relation to the Lurgan campus of Craigavon Senior High School.
 
“We will continue to support the staff and governors of Craigavon Senior High School as they seek to continue to improve standards and care for the pupils on both campuses.
 
"Craigavon Senior High School is an important part of the Dickson Plan family of schools and will continue to receive the support it requires.
 
“In the longer term, any proposal for change will be subject to a full consultation process and we will continue to engage with all relevant stakeholders.”
 
 Parents urged to talk about stranger danger following 'sexting' incident 
 
 Keep up-to-date with all the very latest news, what's on, sport and everything else in Belfast and beyond with the Belfast Live app. 
 
 Only select news that interests you by picking the topics you want to display on the app's homepage. Plus, our enhanced user experience includes live blogs, video, interactive maps and slick picture galleries. Download it now and get involved. 
 
  Click here to get it from the App Store or here for Google Play .
item.title: Bitter battle to save troubled Craigavon Senior High from closure

item.body:
Saturday's estimated Lotto jackpot is £5 million after nobody scooped Wednesday's top prize.
 
The winning Lotto numbers were 45, 41, 57, 58, 54, 04 and the bonus number was 26.
 
Set of balls five and Draw machine Merlin were used.
 
One person matched five balls plus the bonus ball to win £43,378, while 29 ticket-holders matched five balls to scoop £1,574 each.
 
 
 Lotto jackpot hits £17.2 million after nobody wins Wednesday draw 
 
A total of 1,631 people matched four balls to win £180, while 40,598 people matched three balls to win £25.
 
No-one won the £350,000 jackpot in the Lotto HotPicks draw.
 
What happens when you win the lottery? 
 Amanda Lewis won the lottery - and still works at Asda 
 
The winning Thunderball numbers were 35, 07, 05, 37, 22 and the Thunderball number was 4.
 
No-one won the £500,000 top prize.
item.title: Saturday's Lotto jackpot hits £5million after Wednesday draw

item.body:
A Chelsea-based socialite whose grandfather founded the UK's leading food wholesalers will be joining the cast of Love Island.
 
Charlie Brake, 23, is one of 12 new contestants set to stir up drama on the ITV2 dating show when they arrive during Thursday's episode.
 
He said: "I think a lot of people when they find out about my background, there might be a lot of jealousy there.
 
"My grandfather founded a food distribution company called Brakes which my family own and we sold it so everyone is well looked after.
 
"I visit my dad in Monaco a lot and spend a lot of time in the French Alps."
 
He is one of a raft of new men entering the house vying for the affections of Megan Barton Hanson and Ellie Brown.
 
He said: "My type on paper is blonde, blue eyes, petite and curvy. I've got my eye on Ellie and Megan."
 
 
Jordan Adefeyisan, 23, a model from Stockport, also said he has eyes for the duo, as well as Georgia Steel.
 
He said he is interested in "a nice girl, with good banter and who I can click with properly".
 
He added: "In the villa, I fancy Ellie, Megan and Georgia is fit as well. I know they are coupled up but it's all a game isn't it?"
 
Frankie Foster, 22, a student and fitness coach from Cheltenham, is also interested in Ellie, as well as newcomer Zara McDermott.
 
He said: "It would be nice to find someone that I genuinely click with; obviously there are a lot of good looking people in there, but I'd like to end up finding someone I really like.
 
"I change my mind in terms of who I like every time I watch it - but at the moment it is probably Ellie and Zara.
 
"They both seem cool and chatty. They're most similar to my usual type."
 
 Love Island's Wes stuns fellow contestants by hooking up with Megan - straight after Laura split 
 
He will face competition from Dean Overson, 25, a car salesman from Burnley, who said: "They've got to have a lovely smile.
 
"I like nice eyes and I want a girl to have a bit about them, someone you can speak to and who can hold a conversation.
 
"I like Megan and I'd go for Ellie. Zara is beautiful as well. I think all of the girls are lovely in their own way."
 
Love Island 2018 
They will be joined by semi-professional footballer Jack Fowler, 22, from London and Alex Miller, a 28-year-old structural glazier from Essex, who has eyes for Dani Dyer, who is currently coupled up with Jack Fincham.
 
He said: "Petite brunettes are my type. In the villa I like Dani. I like Ellie too, she's cute.
 
"Dani is very coupled up with Jack so we'll have to see how coupled up they really are when I go in..."
 
 Meet the 12 new bombshells poised to join Love Island 
 
Love Island continues on ITV2 at 9pm.
item.title: Love Island newboy Charlie plans to make a move for Megan

item.body:
It's official. Almost a year on from agreeing a deal with RB Leipzig to sign him, Liverpool have officially unveiled Naby Keita.
 
The Guinea international has already been hyped to high heaven as a player who can take Jurgen Klopp's team to the next level, as serious competitors for the Premier League, the Champions League and a threat to Manchester City and their dominance over the English topflight.
 
During his time in the Bundesliga, the 23-year-old marked himself out as one of the most exciting talents in Europe in his position. If a mad scientist were to create a midfielder fit for the modern game, splicing together bits and pieces from other top players, they would struggle to come up with a better end product than the Guinean.
 
 Why Arsenal were never interested in signing Manchester United's Marouane Fellaini 
 
He can dribble past opponents and keep the ball like Tottenham Hotspur's Mousa Dembele. When in possession, he has a wonderful eye for a killer pass to evade defenders, not unlike David Silva. 
 
Despite standing at only five-foot-eight, he can shrug off opponents and surge into the final third as Kevin De Bruyne and Paul Pogba often do for the Manchester clubs. His father gave him the middle name of "Deco" given his resemblance to the former Porto, Barcelona and Chelsea playmaker as a footballer.
 
 
 
 
Keita is quick, clever and hard-working and arrives at Liverpool having already proven his ability to be a match-winner for Leipzig, closing down the opposition.
 
For Jurgen Klopp, he will replace the gold dust qualities of Philippe Coutinho as a player who can make something out of nothing while also slotting into the German's demands for a high press to put other teams under serious pressure, home and away.
 
"A complete No. 8," was the description given by Michel Dussuyer, who handed Keita his first international cap in 2014, as reported by the official Bundesliga website. 
 
 Who is Gelson Martins? - The Arsenal and Liverpool transfer target who could sign for free 
 
Over the last two seasons he has scored 14 goals and bagged 12 assists in the German topflight and ranks as one of Europe's most prolific and effective dribblers.
 
So what do Arsenal, Chelsea, Crystal Palace, Fulham, Tottenham Hotspur, Watford and West Ham need to worry about when it comes to facing Keita next season?
 
Where does Naby Keita play? 
For RB Leipzig, Keita usually played as one of the central midfielders in front of their back four.
 
The Bundesliga outfit play an aggressive and expansive brand of football focused around fast breaks and intense pressing to win the ball high up the field.
 
Marcel Sabitzer and Arsenal target Emil Forsberg would be deployed ahead of Keita and his more defensive partner Diego Demme. It was their job to peel away to run the channels or pick out their teammates with deliveries from the half space, where Mesut Ozil and De Bruyne often roam in the Premier League.
 
 Mesut Ozil's struggles for Germany at the World Cup 2018 show why he needs Unai Emery 
 
For Liverpool, Keita could replace Emre Can as the more dynamic midfielder alongside Jordan Henderson. The England international would hope to build a similar on-field relationship to the one that the Guinean enjoyed with Demme. Fabinho is another option to partner the former Leipzig man.
 
Alternatively, he could be sent further up the pitch to play that role that Adam Lallana often takes up when fit as an attacking midfielder tasked with triggering the press behind Mohamed Salah, Sadio Mane and Roberto Firmino.
 
What is Naby Keita's style of play? 
Keita is a box-to-box midfielder with a low centre of gravity, good pace and an excellent eye for a pass. He moves well and regularly makes runs into the final third in the hopes of creating or scoring goals.
 
Yet unlike other attacking midfielders, he works hard off the ball and contributes to his team's defensive efforts, intercepting threats and challenging opponents to win back possession.
 
 Andreas Christensen scouting report: Defender now gives Maurizio Sarri more options in midfield 
 
His standard mode of play is to bring the ball forward from deep, either running in possession or playing short, simple passes to advance the play up the pitch where he can use his strength on the ball and dribbling ability to take opponents out of the game in tight spaces.
 
Even when he isn't able to get past his markers, he usually wins a foul to put his colleagues in a dangerous position for a freekick.
 
What are Naby Keita's weaknesses? 
The Guinean's lack of height can be an issue although any players who have spent time alongside him will know that passing to his feet is an easy solution to that flaw - and Santi Cazorla and Silva have shown just how dominant diminutively-framed midfielders can be in the Premier League in recent years for Arsenal and Manchester City, respectively.
 
 How Lucas Torreira will unlock Granit Xhaka's true potential at Arsenal under Unai Emery 
 
However, one fault that isn't so easily covered for is Keita's indiscipline. The midfielder picked up 15 yellow cards and two reds in his two seasons in the German topflight.
 
If he can be put under pressure and made to feel as if the world is against him, especially when decisions don't go his way, his reactions can get the better of him. Think Roy Keane.
 
How to stop Naby Keita 
West Ham look set to be the first London club to face the Guinean in a Liverpool shirt when they face the Reds on August 11 at Anfield.
 
Manuel Pellegrini will need to make sure his defence has plenty of cover, not only to deter Salah and his wing-mates, but to stop Keita building up the momentum he thrives on by working the play forward from deep to explode into the final third to cause chaos. 
 
That's easier said than done but it will be key to have at least one extra player in midfielder to plug gaps, close down his options and keep tabs on him. No wonder the Irons have been linked with moves for a number of midfielders to reinforce their options.
 
 Steven N'Zonzi showed why Chelsea and Arsenal have looked elsewhere following France display 
 
Next up could be Crystal Palace, who already have Luka Milivojevic to try and guard their own defenders but will need a big shift from their wingers and attacking players to try and unsettle Keita and disrupt his passing game higher up the pitch, before he becomes a problem for the Eagles in their own half. 
 
August 18 is the date. Selhurst Park will be the venue.
 
Spurs face Liverpool on September 15, and spectators could be in for a treat as Keita comes up against the likes of Dele Alli, Eric Dier and Mousa Dembele, or whoever is signed to replace the Belgian if he departs in the transfer window.
 
 Mateo Kovacic is the readymade upgrade on Mousa Dembele that Spurs cannot miss out on this summer 
 
Mauricio Pochettino's side have often cancelled out Klopp and his Liverpool team and this should be another contest that relies upon individual battles being won, especially in midfield.
 
Chelsea host Liverpool on September 29 and given the uncertainty over who will be taking charge next season, it's hard to say what shape they will line up in or how their approach could change, but N'Golo Kante will undoubtedly be important in any battle to contain Keita.
 
Their duel would be akin to an immovable object meeting an unstoppable force and could be a fascinating encounter.
 
 No new manager, no signings, no direction: Chelsea set for their most frustrating summer yet 
 
Arsenal are set to welcome Liverpool to the Emirates on November 3. If Unai Emery has signed another midfielder by the time of the visit, Klopp and Keita may be faced with another day of one-on-one battles as Granit Xhaka, Aaron Ramsey and a third player, perhaps Lucas Torreira, step up to the plate.
 
Fulham and Watford have to wait until November 10 and November 24, respectively, to take on the Reds. The Cottagers are likely to try and fight fire with fire and be positive, playing on the front-foot to hope their fast attackers can pose questions at the other end while the Hornets have players of their own to put forward to counter Keita in Abdoulaye Doucoure and Nathaniel Chalobah.
 
No matter the personnel available to his opponents, Keita is set to be a headache for London clubs to deal with over the course of the season to come.
 
 Why Lucas Vazquez is the final piece in the Arsenal jigsaw for Unai Emery and Sven Mislintat 
 
Keep up to date with the latest news, features and exclusives from football.london via the free football.london app for iPhone and Android.
 
Available to download from the App Store and Google Play.

item.body:
Firefighters are tackling a large grass fire on open land near Holmfirth.
 
West Yorkshire Fire and Rescue Service says the blaze, near Digley Reservoir car park,covers a 20m by 20m area.
 
A spokeswoman said two engines from Huddersfield and Meltham were sent to the scene after the fire was reported at 9.07pm.
 
She said firefighters had not called for back up, which indicated they were confident of being able to put it out between them using beaters and water.
 
 
 She said it was nowhere near the scale of the operation in Saddleworth, where 100 firefighters have been working today to put out an enormous blaze which has been raging since Monday. 
 
It started on Sunday when it was brought under control, but it reignited on Monday and has been going ever since.

item.body:
Arsenal fans may just want to hold off before getting Ozil No.11 printed on their shirt ahead of next season.
 
While there is little chance of the German international leaving the Emirates having penned a new long-term contract back in February, a change of squad number could well be on the cards before the big kick-off in August.
 
Petr Cech, Hector Bellerin, Mohamed Elneny and Granit Xhaka have all taken on new shirt numbers following a number of exits, while Stephan Lichtsteiner will wear the No.12 jersey from next season.
 
With only a few squad numbers available at present, including the No.3 and No.5 shirts, one famous number at Arsenal has just become available following Jack Wilshere's decision to end his long association with the Gunners.
 
Worn by Paul Merson, Dennis Bergkamp and Robin van Persie in the past, as well as defender William Gallas for four seasons, Wilshere's exit means that the No.10 shirt is now up for grabs.
 
 
 
 
Mesut Ozil has made no secret of his desire to wear the shirt since his arrival back in 2013 and he previously spoke about what the number meant to him having inherited it for the German national team.
 
"For me, the number means a lot. It’s my favourite number," he said. 
 
"Football legends such as Zinedine Zidane, Diego Maradona or Pele wore that number on the back. I’m really happy about it.
 
"Of course I have previously given those in charge a signal. The number is right for me and my position as a playmaker."
 
Although the German is currently on World Cup duty with his country, don't be surprised if he sent the club a quick message about acquiring the shirt number upon hearing about Wilshere's exit.
 
 Transfer news live: Emery says 'yes' to £21m Arsenal deal, star says he chooses Man United 
 
The 29-year-old, who has worn the No.11 shirt since signing from Real Madrid five years ago, is desperate to get his hands on the top and now it looks like he will finally get his wish.
 
In fact, Ozil had even wanted the shirt number following Wilshere's loan move to Bournemouth during the 2016/17 season.
 
Speaking to German publication Kicker, he said: "Since Wilshere’s departure last summer, the number is free, but I have yet to get it."
 
In a further interview with the Express, he added: "[The No.10] has become free and I definitely want it."
 
 
 
 
Given clubs don't usually assign the squad numbers for players that have departed on loan, Ozil was made to wait.
 
Reports had even suggested last year that the player would only sign a new long-term contract with the club providing he could take on Wilshere's shirt number.
 
Having worn the shirt during his time with Real Madrid and on international duty with Germany, it looks like Arsenal will have a new No.10 on the pitch come the opening day against Manchester City.
 
 Unai Emery gives Arsenal the green light to launch £21m bid for World Cup 2018 star - report 
 
 
 
Keep up to date with the latest news, features and exclusives from football.london via the free football.london app for iPhone and Android.
 
Available to download from the App Store and Google Play.
item.title: Mesut Ozil is about to finally see his wish granted at Arsenal after waiting five long years

item.body:
As a child, Meiner wanted to be a barrister. She was very intelligent and everybody around her thought she would go far. 
 
However, at the age of 13, she was prescribed Valium, which is used to treat anxiety, following her father’s death.
 
It ruined her life. Four decades later, aged 55, she sees a direct link from that valium to the sleeping tablets and painkillers she would take as a young woman and ultimately heroin.
 
 Meiner lives in Cwmgors in Neath Port Talbot . Her story is a chilling one about the consequences of additiction and the challenges addicts face. 
 
 
“Valium was my first drug - looking back, Valium ruined my teenage years,” she added. “At the time, doctors didn’t realise how addictive they were.
 
“I was a very intelligent kid and everybody thought I would go very far.
 
“When I was eight or nine, I remember wanting to be a barrister. I do blame the doctors for giving me Valium at such young age.”
 
She describes her upbringing as "ok" and says she dropped out of school at the age of 16 to work in a motor factory, making components for cars.
 
 When she was around 26 or 27, she was prescribed Temazepam, a sleeping tablet. At the time she was working in a nursing home in Ammanford and she quickly got addicted to the jelly-like painkillers as well. 
 
“With all the medication, I haven’t got much of a memory. I find it hard to look that back,” Meiner said, finding it hard to recollect much detail.
 
 Heroin and a Welsh town: Addiction, violence and tragedy in a small corner of Wales 
 
Meiner was 30 when she first tried heroin; she couldn’t get Valium or Temazepam so she turned to the class A drug.
 
As she suffers from anxiety and depression, she used heroin to self-medicate her mental health. She felt heroin helped her relax and helped her with her depression.
 
As a heroin addict, it was hard, Meiner said. At the time, she was living in Swindon as she had had to flee an abusive relationship. At first, Meiner was still able to keep agency work, working in nursing homes.
 
“The first time I had heroin, I can remember thinking this is the drug for me because it calms me down,” she said. “Despite all the medication, I was still a bit hyper.”
 
 
 
At her worst, Meiner was spending £100 a day on heroin. She would fund her habit through her partners, who she said would be dealing drugs or would go out stealing to get money for heroin.
 
She has never been one to use drugs in crowds, Meiner said, she was more of a “secret user”.
 
“I didn’t want to show because I was embarrassed,” she continued. “I only ever took heroin - if I was a drinker, I would be dead now.”
 
In her mid 40s, Meiner moved back to Wales, which is when she first went into treatment. At one point, she went to a rehab clinic in Weston Super Mare.
 
“I have been trying to get clean for 15 years,” she said. “There is a lot of stigma around being a heroin addict, it is not something I am proud of.”
 
 Original journalism from WalesOnline... 
 
Meiner said she hasn’t touched heroin since February this year, when she was prescribed Subutex, used to treat opioid addiction, via Dyfodol - part of the Kaleidoscope group and which provides the prescribing service for the criminal justice system. She has been travelling to Neath to get the drug every day since then.
 
Meiner, who was convicted for shoplifting offences years ago, is only able to get help through the criminal justice system as the community drug and alcohol team class her to be an immediate threat following a series of disputes.
 
The health board would not comment on Meinir's case when we approached it but referred us to their guidance on process.
 
It states: "When a referral is received a risk assessment is completed by the clinical team to determine if treatment can be safely provided. Where this is not considered possible the patient is signposted to alternative appropriate services.”
 
Because Meinir is being treated under through the criminal justice system, she said her treatment will be cut off in February 2019 after one year.
 
She finds it hard to keep going when she feels the help is going to be cut off while she still needs it, adding she will be forced to buy Subutex off the streets, which will cost her £10 a day.
 
 
Meiner - who is from the Ammanford area originally - wishes she could continue the treatment through the community addiction teams.
 
“My life would be easier if I was just taking heroin but I don’t want to,” she added. “It shouldn’t be a battle to get treatment. It is a continuous fight to stay clean.”
 
Meiner - who hasn’t worked for more than fifteen years but has volunteered in charity shops - said she was first prescribed Subutex in 2013 and that when she was taken off the drug then, she had repeated nervous breakdowns.
 
 From a life of crime to international rugby - the stunning tale of redemption that does Wales proud 
 
The 55-year-old said: “I am petrified because the medication ends in February next year. I have been fighting to get clean and get medication.
 
“They are denying me treatment. At the end of the year, I am going to be another statistic of death.
 
“I worry about it every single day. I have had to cut my hair short because I was getting into such state that I was pulling my hair out.
 
“Life was easier on heroin, which is absurd.”
 
 
Martin Blakebrough, CEO of Kaleidoscope, said the key problem with some services is that they are very quick to ban.
 
“In normal circumstances, like attending A&E, I could understand but there seems little allowance for mental illness, or temporary illness that can make people difficult,” he added. “In this case my understanding is that Meiner has made threats which have led her to been banned for life from the community drug and alcohol team.
 
“I cannot understand how anyone can be banned for life regardless of the threat. The reality is many people we work with have significant mental health issues which does mean they are volatile.”
 
Mr Blakebrough said that Meiner has treatment with Dyfodol until February and, provided they can still manage her needs, they would hope that the commissioners in the area would allow them to continue her treatment if that was her wish.
 
“I think it is vital that people such as Meiner are given as much support to maintain treatment as possible because the cost of not doing is too high for her and the community,” he continued. “As the Government have announced more community sentences for women we need to plan better to support the most needy in our community and not shut the door on them and their possible progress.”
 
Karen Jones, chair of the Western Bay Area Planning Board, said it would not be appropriate for her to discuss an individual case.
 
She said: “The APB seeks to be assured that services are delivered appropriately to meet people’s needs, that there is good liaison with criminal justice services and that any complaints are addressed properly.”
item.title: The real life story of a 55-year-old woman who is addicted to heroin
