item.body:
A former flame of Love Island star Jack Fincham is among the 12 new bombshells poised to join the ITV2 dating show.
 
Ellie Jones, 22, dated the pen salesman after they met in August 2016 and even spoke to him two days before he went on the show.
 
Jack has been happily coupled up with Dani Dyer, the daughter of EastEnders star Danny Dyer, since the start of the series and Ellie said she would not revisit their romance.
 
She said: "We have always spoken because we got on so well.
 
"I actually spoke to him as a friend about two days before he went into the villa and had no idea he was going on the show!
 
"We weren't in an official relationship but we spoke about it, would go on dates and kept trying to make it work but it wouldn't. I met his brother and mates. I don't know how he'll feel when he sees me walk in.
 
"I don't know if he'll be angry or shocked but we do get on so hopefully it won't be an issue.
 
"When I look at him, I do still think there is something there but I would never go back there."
 
 
She is one of 12 new contestants set to stir up drama on the dating series and said she has her eye on Josh Denzel and doctor Alex George, saying of the medic: "He's so different to my normal type, I think I'm in love with him already and I've not even met him yet!
 
 Two Love Island stars will be booted off show tonight - and they might not even be a couple 
 
"He makes my heart melt, he'll be a good person to bring home to my parents."
 
Also joining the show will be 22-year-old dancer Savanna Darnell, from Sheffield, and 25-year-old hairdresser Grace Wardle from London, as well as make-up artist Kazimir Crossley, 23, also from London.
 
They will be accompanied by Charlie Williams, 24, a tanning shop assistant from Bath, who is also keen on Alex and new arrival Sam Bird.
 
 
 
Twitter Reacts: Niall leaves Love Island 
 
 
She said: "I really like Alex - I like him more the more that I watch the show. His values are so strong. I think we'd have a lot in common.
 
"The new guy Sam also seems really funny; I think I would get on with him."
 
 Love Island's Wes stuns fellow contestants by hooking up with Megan - straight after Laura split 
 
Darylle Sargeant, 24, a heavily tattooed eyebrow technician from Watford who used to date The Only Way Is Essex star Dean Ralph, could be set to stir up drama between Adam Collard and Zara McDermott when she joins the show.
 
She said: "I like tall, dark and handsome! I am really tattooed so I love heavily tattooed guys but I also like people who have good chat and banter, someone who isn't too serious.
 
"In the villa, I've got my eye on Adam, he is beautiful. I like Jack too and Josh."
 
 
 
Love Island 2018 
 
 
Here's everything you need to know about the new islanders.
 
The Girls 
Savanna Darnell 
 
Savanna is a 22-year-old dancer/singer from Sheffield.
 
Savanna is looking for a guy she can be herself around and wants to have an "amazing experience" in the villa.
 
No stranger to love Savanna has had three long term relationships, with her exes most likely to describe her as "expensive."
 
She said: "They say they end up spending a lot of money. But that’s them spending their money, I don’t ask them to! I’m considered quite unpredictable too. You don’t know from one day to the next what I’ll be like."
 
Grace Wardle 
 
Grace is a 25-year-old hairdresser from London.
 
The stylist is looking for long-term love in the villa, after only having one serious relationship.
 
She believes her eyes and her boobs are her best attributes, saying "Physically my eyes, and my breasts, as I paid for them so if they weren’t great I would be quite annoyed!"
 
Grace isn't afraid to create drama to get her man, but said she would talk things through with another girl, before going after their partner.
 
Charlie Williams 
 
Charlie is a 24-year-old tanning assistant from Bath.
 
Charlie describes what she wants from the villa as "in a nutshell I want someone nice, hard working and someone who wants to be in a genuine relationship."
 
And she's already got her eye on two of the boys saying: "I really like Alex –I like him more the more that I watch the show. His values are so strong. I think we’d have a lot in common. The new guy Sam also seems really funny; I think I would get on with him."
 
Kazimir Crossley 
 
Kazimir is a 23-year-old make-up artist from London.
 
Kazimir has done last year's winner Kem's make-up before and has been asking him for tips ahead of her entrance to the show.
 
Georgia best watch out as Kazimir has already set her eyes on Josh, saying: "I want to find an honest guy because I’ve come across so many liars. I like to be looked after. In the villa, I fancy Josh."
 
Adam's antics also failed to impress Kazimir, as she said: "What Adam did to Rosie puts me off, he gets what he wants and he needs to learn you can’t always get what you want."
 
Ellie Jones 
 
The 22-year-old admin assistant will be familiar to one islander - as she used to go out with Jack.
 
Speaking about their relationship she said: "I was seeing Jack Fincham on and off. We met in August 2016 and dated on and off for a while.
 
"We have always spoken because we got on so well. I actually spoke to him as a friend about two days before he went into the villa and had no idea he was going on the show!
 
"We weren’t in an official relationship but we spoke about it, would go on dates and kept trying to make it work but it wouldn’t.
 
"I met his brother and mates. I don’t know how he’ll feel when he sees me walk in.
 
"I don’t know if he’ll be angry or shocked but we do get on so hopefully it won’t be an issue. When I look at him, I do still think there is something there but I would never go back there."
 
While she might not be keen to rekindle things with Jack Ellie has got her eyes on another two islanders.
 
She said: "I fancy Josh. And I really fancy Alex because he’s so different to my normal type, I think I’m in love with him already and I’ve not even met him yet! He makes my heart melt, he’ll be a good person to bring home to my parents."
 
Darylle Sargeant 
 
Darylle is a 24-year-old eyebrow technician from Watford.
 
Darylle used to date Towie star Dean Ralph and says the pair have remained friends.
 
The tattoo loving babe is keen to find a kindred spirit in the villa and already knows who she wants, saying: "I like tall, dark and handsome! I am really tattooed so I love heavily tattooed guys but I also like people who have good chat and banter, someone who isn’t too serious.
 
"In the villa, I've got my eye on Adam, he is beautiful. I like Jack too and Josh."
 
The Boys 
Jordan Adefeyisan 
 
Jordan is a 23-year-old model from Stockport.
 
He describes his ideal girl as "A nice girl, with good banter and who I can click with properly. In the villa, I fancy Ellie, Megan and Georgia is fit as well. I know they are coupled up but it's all a game isn't it..."
 
Jordan has never had a serious relationship, but hates girls with attitude who think they are better than other people.
 
Charlie Brake 
 
Charlie is a 23-year-old socialite from Chelsea.
 
Charlie has already got his eye on Ellie and Megan in the villa and says he thinks people may be jealous of his family fortune.
 
He said: "I think a lot of people when they find out about my background, there might be a lot of jealousy there.
 
"My grandfather founded a food distribution company called Brakes which my family own and we sold it so everyone is well looked after.
 
"I visit my Dad in Monaco a lot and spend a lot of time in the French Alps."
 
Charlie has a Scouse ex, who will be surprised to see him on the show, as he explained: "I met another girl who was from Liverpool and ended up being with her for about a year and half and moved to America with her for a bit.
 
"Then it came to end. I reckon they’ll be surprised to see me on Love Island."
 
Frankie Foster 
 
Frankie is a 22-year-old business management student and fitness coach from Cheltenham.
 
Frankie used to play semi-professional rugby and says he's not the "stereotypical lad in skinny jeans and tight T shirts."
 
Ellie and Zara are the girls who have caught his attention as he described what he wants from the villa as: "I’d like to end up finding someone I really like. I change my mind in terms of who I like every time I watch it –but at the moment it is probably Ellie and Zara.
 
"They both seem cool and chatty. They’re most similar to my usual type."
 
Jack Fowler 
 
Jack in a 22-year-old semi-professional footballer from London.
 
Jack previously starred in a Tom Zanetti music video and is looking forward to his villa experience.
 
Keeping his cards close to his chest about his villa crush Jack said he was looking for a "brunette girl who is curvy with a nice bum and a nice smile and nice eyes. But we also need a connection."
 
Previously Jack has lied about his age to get a girl, he said: "I wanted to be with a girl who was a bit older than me so when I was 19, 20, I changed my age on Tinder to 25.
 
"I met a girl on there who was 24 and we had a date but when I got my wallet out to pay, she checked my ID and her face dropped when she saw I was younger than I’d said."
 
Alex Miller 
 
Alex is a 28-year-old structural glazier from Essex.
 
Alex describes himself as "pretty perfect" and says petite brunettes are his type.
 
He said: "In the villa I like Dani. I like Ellie too, she’s cute. Dani is very coupled up with Jack so we’ll have to see how coupled up they really are when I go in…"
 
Alex's advice to girls who want to woo him is: "Be bubbly, I don’t like boring birds. As long as they are funny and have a good personality. When it comes to my ideal date, I’ve got a great first date that I’ve done a few times – drinks in the city, onto a comedy show and then more drinks. I’ve got a good success ratio with that one!"
 
Dean Overson 
 
Dean is a 25-year-old car salesman from Burnley.
 
Newly single Dean is excited to have some fun in the villa and has his eye on several girls.
 
He said: "I like nice eyes and I want a girl to have a bit about them, someone you can speak to and who can hold a conversation.
 
"I like Megan and I’d go for Ellie. Zara is beautiful as well. I think all of the girls are lovely in their own way."
 
Dean's turn-offs are loud girls, as he said: "Someone who is very loud and a bit too much. And also if a girl thinks she is better than what she is. Like when you’re out and trying to speak to a girl and she is arrogant."
 
Love Island continues on ITV2 at 9pm. The new arrivals will appear during Thursday's episode.

item.body:
Home Bargains have recalled Malibu SPF 30 Dry Oil Spray as the product contains no protection from the sun.
 
Eagle-eyed shoppers posted on Hotukdeals to alert the public of this recall.
 
According to the product recall poster, the Malibu dry oil spray is being recalled as it contains the wrong formula.
 
It reads: "The product contains Fast Tanning Oil which does not contain SPF30. There is a potential risk to the consumer if this product is used as it will not provide protection against the sun."
 
Home Bargains advised those who have bought the product, to make sure you do not use it and return it to the store where the product was purchased as soon as possible or contact Malubi for a refund.
 
Should customers have any queries, they can contact Malibu on 01923 289 470.
 
The affected product is: 
Barcode: 5025135116278
 
Batch Code: 18086
 
No other products are affected by this recall.
item.title: Home Bargains recall Malibu Factor 30 sun spray as it has no sun protection

item.body:
Heidi Allen has asked the Prime Minister to set up a dedicated taskforce to tackle the chaos blighting Govia Thameslink Railway (GTR) services.
 
The South Cambridgeshire MP read out an email from a constituent detailing his nightmare journey to London at Prime Minister's Questions today (June 27).
 
Mrs Allen has also joined two other MPs in writing to the Government to demand an urgent response to service failures.
 
British rail users travelling on Thameslink, Southern and Great Northern - all run by GTR - have been hit by delays and cancellations since the failed introduction of new timetables in May.
 
GTR has apologised for the ongoing problems and said it is working to launch an improved temporary timetable in July.
 
 
Speaking in the Commons this afternoon, Mrs Allen said: "At 6.49 am my constituent, James Wheatcroft, emailed me to say: 'I am currently standing at Shepreth station. 06.40 has just arrived. 05.38, 06.10 and 07.25 bus cancelled so this is on the only train to London this morning until the 8.10.'
 
"'Five people have been on the platform for over an hour and missed their Eurostar connection. The station car park is totally empty - people giving up and working from home.'
 
"At 7.29 am he sent another message: 'Our train has now broken down. Another train has arrived but there is not enough room for everyone.'
 
”At 7.59 am, he said that the rest of the passengers had to get train back north, there was no room for them on that either and that 'people simply decided to go home'."
 
I've given up on trains entirely - they're always late
 
Mrs Allen added: "Please, Prime Minister - assurances from Govia Thameslink Railway are not enough. We need a taskforce to micromanage these contracts back to performance. Will she please commit to that?
 
Theresa May said she recognised Mrs Allen's concerns and said that passengers' experience had been unacceptable.
 
 
She added: "The Department for Transport has been working on this issue with GTR, and it is working to provide a new timetable, which will provide more capacity on the services, but it is not the same timetable that was originally introduced in May.
 
"The Department for Transport will continue to work to ensure that the rail company is providing the performance that passengers rightly expect and deserve."
 
A letter signed by Mrs Allen, Sir Oliver Heald, MP for North East Hertfordshire and Jonathan Djanogly, MP for Huntingdon highlighted their "concern and disappointment" at the five weeks of issues being faced by commuters.
 
12,000 train journeys cancelled as rail misery continues across the UK
 
Writing to transport minister Jo Johnson, the MPs said they had received a "substantial" amount of complaints from constituents.
 
These include cancelled trains at rush hour, trains too full to board, poorly communicated timetable changes, too long gaps between peak hour services, "abysmal" weekend services.
 
They said shift and emergency workers were struggling to reach their workplaces due to cancelled services.
 
 
"We ask for a detailed response to each concern raised and assurances that these concerns are being addressed as a matter of urgency," they wrote.
 
"In the spirit of collaboration, we have each worth with GTR to share users' concerns and we have communicated your assurances to commuters that things are improving.
 
"The anecdotal evidence that we are receiving suggests that commuters are still experiencing service levels well below 'emergency' expectations."
 
The MPs questioned why possible tweaks to timetables run by other train operators had not been down.
 
They also claimed passengers were still "in the dark" about the compensation offer made to them by Great Northern. They requested that enhanced compensation should be made available to affected passengers.
 
"Passengers are fed up of hearing that 'things are going to improved'," the wrote.
 
"Five weeks of emergency planning has not stabilised the service sufficiently to restore our confidence in GTR as an operator."
item.title: 'Abysmal' rail services need to be sorted, says MP Heidi Allen

item.body:
A 20-year-old man was found fatally stabbed after reports of a fight, Scotland Yard has said.
 
Police are investigating his death on Wednesday as a murder, bringing the total number of such investigations launched in London this year to at least 81.
 
The Metropolitan Police said officers were called shortly after 6.30pm to reports of a brawl between men armed with baseball bats in Cavendish Road, Edmonton, north London.
 
 
 Armed police launch manhunt after terrified pensioner robbed of his car at gunpoint in Coleshill 
 
The man had stab wounds and was pronounced dead at the scene despite the efforts of paramedics.
 
"At this early stage officers retain an open mind as to motive," a force spokesman said.
 
Further crime scenes remained open in nearby Brettenham Road and Cameron Close and officers are trying to identify the man's next of kin, he added.
 
Knife crime round-up 
Anyone with information should contact 101 or Crimestoppers anonymously on 0800 555 111.

item.body:
Two new shops, a major café refurbishment and a slide down to the beach are among the exciting plans for Southport Pier following a £3m transformation.
 
The owners of Southport Pier Pavilion Café, Colin Jamieson and his daughters, Natalie Jamieson-Morrison and Joanne Jamieson, are also putting in a “significant investment” of their own.
 
The landmark structure, which was opened in August 1860, is the oldest iron pier in the country and at a length of 1,108m (3,635ft) is the second-longest in Great Britain, after Southend Pier.
 
Natalie and Joanne run the cafe, and are planning to expand their empire as they look to launch an exciting new future for one of Britain’s most historic attractions.
 
 
 
 
The two Victorian shelters on the pier are being converted into two new venues, which will both run by the sisters.
 
One, the Pier Pit Stop, will become an ice cream parlour and bar, which will sell “folded ice cream” and is to open in July.
 
The other will become a shop, most likely a souvenir shop, but an opening date has not yet been confirmed.
 
Additionally, the Southport Pier Pavilion Café will close for three months this winter to undergo refurbishment, to give the venue “a whole new look.” 
 
It will retain its nostalgic charm, though, as it will still feature the vintage arcade.
 
The sisters have also applied for an alcohol licence for their venues, as they want to ensure they are able to host events, such as weddings, music and comedy events, later at night so it doesn’t interfere with the public visiting during the day.
 
What happened to our lidos? And wouldn't it be lovely if we still had them
 
Despite rumours that the pier is to turn into a nightclub, the sisters are certain this will not happen.
 
Joanne, 37, who was formerly an officer for Merseyside police, said: “We will not become a nightclub.
 
“Evening events will be taking place around once every three months, and they will be well planned and all attendees must have tickets purchased in advance, and there will be high security.
 
“We are a coffee shop and bar, it wouldn’t be possible to turn the venue into a club every night, it takes too much work.
 
 
 
 
“Our main focus always is, and always will be, the day time.”
 
 
 
The Jamieson family have had the lease of the Southport Pier Cafe for 10 years, opening in 2008.
 
Natalie, 31, said: “We care about the pier, it isn’t just a job - this is our life.
 
“We have a contact here for 20 years, why would we do anything that could damage our own future and the pier?
 
“Many people have suggested we should be open late during the summer, and we have listened to that and we are trying to make the relevant changes.
 
“We want the people of Southport to come down and support the pier and our local business.”
 
Teen's terror at being threatened with 'hunting knife' during scrambler bike robbery
 
It is hoped that the changes that the sisters and Sefton Council are trying to make will appeal to people of all ages - and will make the pier a destination for all local residents, and tourists, to enjoy.
 
Tens of thousands of people take a walk in Southport’s pier each year, and Natalie and Joanne think their plans mean it will only get busier.
 
In the licensing application, the sisters have sought permission for outside the venue as well, to enable them to host pop-up stalls and events in the summer.
 
The new plans are set to create at least 20 jobs and increase footfall at one of Southport’s most famous attractions.
 
Natalie, who formerly ran the Town Gardens Cafe in Lord Street, said: “We want to make the pier more of a destination for visitors, encouraging people to attend and therefore having a knock-on effect for our town, bringing trade to hotels and restaurants.
 
 
 
 
 
 
“We just want to say that everything we are proposing to do has been discussed with Sefton Council tourism and they are fully behind our plans.
 
“They have been really supportive over the past year whilst we were planning.”
 
These plans are just part of the huge refurbishment set to take place, as Sefton Council secured £2m from the Coastal Community Fund in order to undertake the extensive works to the pier.
 
The overall project will deliver more than £2.9m of improvements creating additional jobs, increasing visitor numbers and securing Southport Pier as a valued asset for many years to come.
 
Gunman explains why he shot man in head in front of Christmas shoppers
 
The refurbishment of the pier structure is being carried out in two stages – the first phase took place in December and the second phase began in March, with the project due to finish in December this year.
 
As part of the works, there is set to be a new access point to the pier constructed and a slide attraction from going from the pier to the beach.
 
Cllr Marion Atkinson, Sefton Council’s Labour cabinet member for regeneration and skills, said: “We are delighted the works on Southport Pier have started, which will truly transform the attraction.
 
“The works will see major improvements that will improve access and add new uses, while enhancing and protecting the pier for years to come.
 
“We firmly believe the money being invested will continue to be a critical element in Sefton’s visitor economy.”
item.title: Exciting £3m plans for Southport Pier revealed - including huge SLIDE and two new shops

item.body:
A man and woman were arrested after a disturbance in Liverpool city centre tonight.
 
Officers on patrol came across an incident at the junction of Berry Street and Duke Street shortly after 7.25pm.
 
While dealing with an incident in the area, an officer is believed to have been assaulted and the pair were taken into custody.
 
Both people were arrested on suspicion of being drunk while in charge of two-year-old boy and assaulting an officer.
 
 
The young boy is now being looked after by a family member as the man and woman have been taken to a police station to be interviewed.
 
Officers have contacted social services over the incident.
 
 First pictures of drug dealer who shot rival in head on busy town centre afternoon 
 
 A spokesperson for Merseyside Police said: "Merseyside Police can confirm that a man and woman have been arrested following an incident in Liverpool city centre today (Wednesday 27 June 2018).   "Patrols on duty in the city centre became aware of a disturbance at the junction of Berry Street and Duke Street shortly after 7.25pm.   "A man and woman were arrested on suspicion of being drunk in charge of a minor, and assaulting a police constable in the execution of their duty. 
 
 Here's why a primary school was put on 'lock down' this afternoon 
 
 "They have been taken to a police station to be interviewed."   Officers are examining CCTV and speaking to witnesses to establish the full circumstances of what happened. 
 
Anyone with information about the incident is asked to contact @MerPolCC on Twitter or call 101.

item.body:
The army was drafted in today to help tackle the huge fire on Saddleworth Moor, which has been raging since Monday.
 
 Fire chiefs called in support from the military , who moved equipment by air to speed up the dousing process. 
 
Today more than 100 firefighters have been working on seven areas of fire in an area spanning up to 6km.
 
Frequent changes in wind direction and searing temperatures have caused extra problems for crews.
 
Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service said an RAF Chinook helicopter was likely to be deployed.
 
 
Dave Keelan, director of emergency response at GMFRS, said: "The request is to assist us to move some high volume pumps by air to locations that we couldn't get them to with vehicles, and also the ability to transport personnel to those more remote areas so we can get there quicker with more people with the water supplies we hope to put in place to try and resolve the incident in a quicker nature.
 
"We are still in detailed discussions with the military over the logistical element of it. They will obviously move as quick as they can to get resources here."
 
Fire on Saddleworth moors that can be seen for miles 
He said transporting two of the high volume pumps to remote locations would give his crews an "excellent quantity of water with a nice main across a big area that we can tap into".
 
Mr Keelan said firefighters were working "extremely hard in really hot conditions" but morale was high as he said: "It's more of a task to get them down here to rest."
 
Firefighters on a total of 29 fire engines from Greater Manchester and neighbouring fire and rescue services used beaters and specialist wildfire equipment to tackle the flames.
 
 
In addition, Greater Manchester Police deployed a helicopter to assess the scene and United Utilities provided a helicopter that can be used to drop water onto remote areas.
 
The blaze, on the edge of Saddleworth Moor, started on Sunday and was brought under control but it reignited the next day and has continued in one of the worst moorland fires to hit the region.
 
The impact of the blaze could even be seen from space as Nasa satellites picked up the plumes of smoke.
 
 
 
space tweet 
 
 
Among the affected areas was the village of Carrbrook, in Stalybridge, where 34 households in the Calico Crescent area were evacuated on Tuesday night when strong winds pushed flames near to their properties.
 
Householders were allowed to return home on Wednesday following air quality assessments.
 
Air quality levels in the area are being monitored regularly in different locations with people in affected areas urged to follow advice from Public Health England and keep their windows and doors closed.
 
 
 
plane tweet 
 
 
Experts warned that high levels of pollutants generated from the blaze could have a significant effect on people's health.
 
Hugh Coe, professor of atmospheric composition at the University of Manchester, said plume peak concentrations were "very high" and air quality close to the fire was "very poor".
 
He said pollution plumes have been detected in the centre of Manchester.
 
Four local schools decided to close on Wednesday for the safety of their pupils.
 
The cause of the original seat of the fire - thought to be at Buckton Hill, which is land above Buckton Vale, Carrbrook - has not been established but fire chiefs said a detailed investigation would be launched at the appropriate time.
 
One possible line of inquiry could focus on the frequent gathering of off-road bikers - many not displaying registered plates - at a nearby large quarry.

item.description: A lifeboat crew was called out after a fishing boat was reported to be in trouble off the north Norfolk coast.
item.body: The Sheringham lifeboat was tasked by Humber Coastguard to search for the boat the Early Bird at 5pm on Tuesday last week. The boat had been reported to be in trouble off the coast of West Runton. With good weather, the lifeboat crew, helmed by David Hagan, with crewmen Chris Taylor, Liam Cooper and Kate Munro, found the boat about 500 metres off the beach at West Runton. The lifeboat crew tried to restart the boat’s engine, to no avail. They then towed the boat and its occupant back to shore at West Runton. The lifeboat then returned to station and was rehoused and ready for serve again at 8pm.
item.title: Lifeboat crew called out to stricken fishing boat off West Runton coast

item.body:
Last time Westminster City Council tried to take on Berwick Street markets, Joanna Lumley got involved and one cheese seller wrote to the Queen. 
 
Street traders have warned it will have another fight on its hands, if it pushes ahead with its proposal to increase charges at some of central London's oldest running street and farmers' markets.
 
The council says the eight markets in the borough are costing too much to run - with street cleansing, waste management and administration saddling it with losses of up to £300,000 a year.
 
It is floating the idea to pass on those costs directly to local market traders.
 
What's happening in west London 
But that idea has not gone down well on Soho's streets.
 
Some Berwick traders run family stalls that have sold treats and wares in the key cultural district for generations.
 
They won a battle to save the market from the council's plans to hand it to a private operator last year.
 
Westminster backed down after the petition to save Berwick Street was signed by more than 37,000 people, including Stephen Fry and Joanna Lumley.
 
Flower trader Laecia Stannett has been selling blooms there since she was a little girl helping out on her dad's stall. She runs Ronnie's Flowers with her brother now.
 
 
She said she believes the council is trying to "gentrify" the markets, and did not support the charges going up - questioning what services the council would offer in exchange for more fees.
 
"Really and truly they didn't really want us here, I don't think," she said. "They've been trying to get rid of us for years. They always give you bigger hurdles, but we've stuck it out and we ain't going nowhere."
 
Berwick Street is one of the capital's oldest surviving markets, believed to have its roots in the 18th century.
 
 Tower Bridge peanut vendors face legal crackdown 
 
It it said to have been the first to sell grapefruit in London, and in Soho's Bohemian heyday, author Virgina Woolf used to buy her nylons there.
 
Today, it is a largely "foodie" destination, but has "seen better days," Soho Dairy owner Robin Smith said.
 
It cost him about £25,000 to set up his stall in 2015. He has had to fight to keep his stall selling artisanal cheeses, milk and eggs to high-end restaurants and cafes, and market visitors.
 
 
Just months after he set up, the council moved to axe his licence as it readied to transfer the market to a private operator.
 
In response, Mr Smith and other traders launched the Berwick Street Traders Society, which was ultimately supported by the star-backed petition.
 
During the battle, Mr Smith said he even wrote to the Queen hoping for records to prove the folklore claiming the markets may have been royally chartered by King James II in the 17th century.
 
The traders planned to tell the council the city's legislation would require it to provide additional services if it increased costs, Mr Smith said.
 
But higher charges are just one hurdle the markets face.
 
Scaffolding backdrops the markets, where local traders say demolitions and the noise of works on luxury retail space developing around their perimeter has drastically affected footfall.
 
 Fear discrimination at London nightclubs is widespread after claim black women charged more for entry 
 
Mr Smith said if the council put up the charges, traders might consider paying up; but only if they were promised it would be invested in better markets.
 
"To put our charges up here they have to have a load of facilities; like we could do with some hygienic new toilet units, we could do with parking, we could do with loading bays, we could do with storage."
 
Mr Smith said many traders still depended on markets, choosing to sell on the streets rather than take on Soho's skyrocketing retail rents.
 
He said Berwick Street should be supported to become a producers' market.
 
"We serve a square mile of chefs and restaurants. So this could be the best produce street in the world, bar none. We have amazing chefs willing to pay sustainable prices for really good, small volume, quality food produce. That could be Berwick Street."
 
 
 So, what could change? 
 
The changes could affect Berwick Street, Church Street, Rupert Street, Strutton Ground, Tachbrook Street, Maida Hill Place market, as well as two weekly farmers' markets at Marylebone and Pimlico.
 
Among the council's proposals, is that local traders could take on more of the costs for cleansing, waste collection, and administration fees through its street market licensing regime, with lower fees paid by local residents and "start up" traders.
 
Presently, the council charges traders licensing fees of £10.61 daily between Monday to Thursday, £18.16 on Fridays, and £24.40 on Saturdays, which have been unchanged since 2006.
 
 Oxford Street pedestrianisation could create a 'problem with beggars' claims Conservative candidate 
 
It is not yet known what price-tag the changes could bring.
 
In unveiling the review, Councillor David Harvey said Westminster's markets had to "continue to hold their own with other markets, on-line retailers and other attractions and provide what local residents want."
 
"I want to discuss with local residents and traders on each market how we can work together to make sure they continue to thrive and serve their neighbourhoods.”
item.title: Berwick Street market traders say they'll put up a fight as they face a possible increase in charges

item.description: AN attempt by a Fermanagh Sinn Féin councillor to change party policy on abortion was “unanimously defeated” at a meeting last Saturday.
item.body:
AN attempt by a Fermanagh Sinn Féin councillor to change party policy on abortion was “unanimously defeated” at a meeting last Saturday.
Sheamus Greene who has previously criticised what he says is “abortion on demand” after the Republic of Ireland voted to reform its strict abortion laws backed a motion at Sinn Fein’s Ard Fheis requesting a conscience vote on the issue.
“I have always supported the party [Sinn Féin] but in this particular case it’s not a view you can change because your party says so,” he told this newspaper earlier this month.
Councillor Greene said then he had no concerns about speaking out against party policy, pointing out that not all members are in agreement.
After the motion by The Fergal O’Hanlon Cumann in Brookeborough was “unanimously defeated” according to a Sinn Féin spokeswoman, Councillor Greene issued a statement pledging to change the policy “from within.”
“Sinn Féin policy has changed on the issue of abortion.
“By tabling this motion we simply sought to accommodate the significant number of pro-life republicans who support the party and who are members.
“Our motion failed on this occasion but I am confident that this will change in the future.
“I have been a Sinn Féin supporter my entire life and will continue to be one. As we have seen, policies can and do change and I will endeavour to make this happen from within the party structures,” he told The Impartial Reporter.
Sinn Fein members, including Fermanagh-south Tyrone MLA Jemma Dolan, voted “decisively” to liberalise abortion law across Ireland.
The motion endorsed by delegates said the procedure should be provided through a GP-led service in a clinical context as determined by law and licensing practice for a limited gestational period.
No exact period was fixed to allow for future changes in medical advice; debate surrounds when a baby is potentially viable outside the womb.
The party also decided terminations should be available where a woman’s life, physical or mental health was at risk and, in cases of fatal foetal abnormality, where an infant could not survive.
Meanwhile Miss Dolan spoke on Irish Unity, telling delegates that partition remains “the fault line through the heart of Ireland.”
“But like Fermanagh winning an Ulster title, a United Ireland has never been more achievable,” she said.
She called on political parties “who claim to support a united Ireland” to “take action and seize the moment.”
Support us in our call for a referendum on Irish Unity. There is a better future to be had for all of us, if we chose to build it, together.”
Seán Lynch discussed a proposal by his party which looks at the feasibility of setting up a “state insurance body” that would deal with the spiralling costs of insurance premiums.
“Whilst the lower rates would definitely be cause to look into this method of delivering insurance, it would also offer greater transparency around the whole process as motorists would know exactly what they are paying for which currently for me is a real issue in the insurance industry,” he said.
Sinn Fein MP Michelle Gildernew told delegates that across the world women’s rights are “under attack in the most vindictive of ways from rape and sexual assault, to female genital mutilation.”
“Many women and children live with the daily reality of domestic violence. Last year alone saw 30,000 reported incidents of domestic violence in the North, and over 3,000 reported sexual offences or rapes.
“That’s an average of 90 incidents per day while underreporting is still recognised as a huge problem.
“The proliferation of violence against women is nothing short of a disgrace,” she said.
In addition, Colm Gildernew MLA spoke on carers and that their rights be placed on a statutory footing and the call for the Electoral Boundary Commission to revert to their initial 2016 proposal.
He also called on the Irish government to release the findings of the Crowley Report into the death of Aidan McAnespie in 1988.

item.body:
A 21-year-old dad who died from a rare form of cancer fulfilled his dream of meeting hero Steven Gerrard - and now his family are planning a special send-off.
 
Daniel McGrath, from Soham, had written a bucket list of things he would like to achieve before he died, including meeting the Liverpool and England legend.
 
The father-of-one was determined to live his last days to the full and leave his nine-month-old daughter Millie heartfelt video messages - but he simply ran out of time
 
Now his own mum Angela, 44, who lives in Girton, is compiling a scrap book of her own to help little Millie remember her much missed dad.
 
Daniel, who only married his wife Rebecca last August, was given just a year to live after Addenbrooke's doctors diagnosed him with an extremely rare stomach cancer in March.
 
He passed away on June 10 surrounded by his family.
 
 
Mum Angela said Daniel spent his last few days supported by the "fantastic" staff at the Arthur Rank Hospice.
 
Her son was receiving pain relief every half an hour and died soon after a visit from his Great Aunt Pat.
 
"I think that was what he was waiting for," said Angela.
 
"He said 'I'm really scared' before he died. I said 'don't be scared, your nan will be waiting for you'.
 
"Everyone thinks I'm mad but his favourite song when he was little was Danny Boy, so I was singing that to him when he died.
 
"I don't know if it comforted him but it comforted me.
 
"I got to say what I needed to say to him and the hospice let me wash him and dress him."
 
 
Angela admitted that the family, including Daniel's 15-year-old brother Kane and 24-year-old sister Lorna, are struggling to come to terms with their loss.
 
"His younger brother is finding it really hard," she said. "He's doing his mock GCSEs this week and he's been quite upset about it.
 
"For me its been a bit of a struggle. I just threw myself into doing stuff rather than thinking about it."
 
 
The family had previously helped Daniel launch a crowdfunding campaign to help him complete a bucket list of dreams to achieve before he died.
 
These included meeting Steven Gerrard and going to a Liverpool match, riding a Harley Davidson, getting a new tattoo and going indoor skydiving.
 
Sadly the rapid decline in his health meant Daniel was not able to complete the full list, but he was overjoyed to go to Liverpool Football Club's home at Anfield and ride a Harley Davidson.
 
 
Photos shared by his mum show a grinning Daniel alongside Liverpool star Mo Salah and giving a thumbs up on the back of a motorbike.
 
During the motorcycle experience in April, around 100 bikers turned up to show their support for Daniel.
 
"He got really emotional about it, said Angela, "He said 'I didn't know this many people cared about me mum' and I said 'everybody loves you Daniel'."
 
 
Angela said it still feels "surreal" to her that Daniel has gone, and she is reminded of him when she looks at his young daughter Millie.
 
"She looks exactly the same as Daniel when he was her age," she explained.
 
"Ive started doing a scrap book for Millie of Daniel, what he was like as a baby and writing little stories of what he was like.
 
"He loved her very much. He was so excited to become a dad. When she was born he was so proud. He just idolised her. It was just a joy to see them together."
 
 
Ahead of Daniel's funeral on June 28, his family have launched a fundraising webpage to raise money for Arthur Rank and say thank you for the care they provided.
 
Members of the Titan MCC motorcycle club will be meeting at the Wheatsheaf pub in Stow-Cum-Quy will be meeting at 11.30am to escort the Daniel to St Mary's Church in Burwell.
 
 
 
 
Angela admitted that it will be a very challenging day for her, but holds on to the happy memories she has of her son.
 
"I will remember him with the cheeky little smile and going mum lets have a laugh," she said.
 
"That's the Daniel I'm going going to remember, who didn't let anything get him down who was always cheerful and happy and up for a laugh."

item.description: Derbyshire Constabulary are appealing for information about an assault at the Greyhound Inn, which left a 43 year old man with serious facial injuries.
item.body: Derbyshire Constabulary are appealing for information about an assault which happened in the Greyhound Inn pub, in Whitemoor Lane, leaving a man with serious facial injuries. The 43-year-old victim told the police that he was in the pub with friends when he was approached by a man who verbally abused him, and then punched him in the face a number of times. The incident happened sometime between 5pm and 5.30pm on Saturday, May 26. If you witnessed the assault, or have any information about it, please call PC Naomi Biggin on 101 quoting reference number 18000251971. Alternatively, send her a message online by visiting the Contact Us section of their website www.derbyshire.police.uk/Contact-Us.

item.description: Two buses took nearly one hundred people from Stroud to a Brexit demonstration in London at the weekend - and the SNJ came along for the ride.
item.body:
Two buses took nearly one hundred people from Stroud to a Brexit demonstration in London at the weekend - and the
came along for the ride.
The plan: depart Stratford Park at 8am on Saturday, June 23, arrive in London for noon, and then join protestors outside Parliament demanding a vote on the final Brexit deal.
And what we wanted to find out: if the pro-EU activists got their way, how did they think Stroud would vote now, in contrast to the Remain result in 2016?
The activists we joined marched under the banner of Glostays, a Gloucestershire group formed in the wake of the Brexit result that campaigns for the UK to remain in the EU.
Once on the bus, we first spoke to Charlie and Eva - in their words a “mixed European couple.”
Charlie is born and bred in Gloucestershire, while Eva is from Germany, having moved to the UK about twenty years ago.
Their concern about Brexit is, firstly, practical: what rights will Eva have in the UK after we leave?
Uncertainty about this straight after the Brexit vote meant they initially considered moving to the continent, but soon dropped the idea.
“We have a lot of friends here, and we’d hate to have to start all over again, rebuilding the relationships we have,” they explained.
And they were sceptical the Government’s proposed ‘settled status’ for EU nationals who arrived in the UK before March 2019 would give Eva just as many freedoms as before.
Such concern was echoed by Nadine and Phil, opposite Charlie and Eva on the bus.
Nadine is also from Germany, having moved to Stroud when she was young, while Phil’s father is Swedish.
They said their biggest fear was being unable to easily visit Nadine’s elderly parents back home.
They also said such anxiety was felt throughout Stroud’s European community, some of which, suggested Phil, had been first drawn to the area by its Steiner schools.
But Charlie and Eva stressed that, for them at least, their concern was not just about the practicalities of living together in a post-Brexit Britain.
“We fear Brexit means there’s no room for a progressive future in the UK,” explained Eva.
Likewise, Charlie was quick to decry seeing the UK embark on a “race to the bottom” after Brexit, and he expected tax and spending cuts. Nadine and Phil later carried a banner at the march that read ‘Brexit = Austerity’.
As they explained this on the bus, their concern soon gave way to frustration. Since the referendum there had been no conversation about what to do to solve the concerns of those who voted Leave, they argued.
But not all protesters predicted post-Brexit doom. For Rob from Gloucester, whose mum had often visited a European town twinned with Tewkesbury, he said he simply felt European and so would just miss being part of the EU.
What did the protestors make of suggestions from some
readers that, in calling for another vote, they were protesting against democracy?
At the same time as the demonstration in London, pro-Brexit campaigners were marching in Gloucester calling for the Prime Minister to respect the original Brexit vote and to stop “dilly dallying”
But those on the Brexit bus, like Antony from Nailsworth, were unphased.
When we put the question to him, he argued: “We’re doing the opposite - our protest is a manifestation of democracy.
“Democracy is not static and people are allowed to change their minds.”
He also denied second vote would re-open the country’s wounds from the fight over the first - “the wounds haven’t healed anyway,” he replied.
Others, like Pauline from Tetbury, took a different line, arguing the original referendum result was based on “lies”, which made it illegitimate.
Pauline was similar to many on the bus, in that either the march was their first protest, or the first for a while - the last time Pauline was at a demo was in the 1980s for a Free Nelson Mandela protest.
But though she had not been particularly active in the 2016 campaign, seeing consequences from Brexit already in her work - her job means she spends time with universities who, she claims, are already losing funding - has energised to get out and campaign on the EU for the first time.
“Beware the angry middle-aged woman,” she warned us.
Similarly, Graham, an elderly Liberal Democrat from Stroud who carried the Glostays banner part way through the streets of London, had never been to a protest before.
But, being old enough to have been born before World War Two, he said he had been motivated to march to keep his grandchildren safe, arguing that Europe needed to “stick together” for the sake of peace.
By and large, protestors from Glostays were on the older rather than younger side, though there were a few exceptions.
Take Tizzy from Rodborough: she had had been too young to vote in 2016 but now, having recently turned 18, she wanted a second vote to cast a first ballot on Brexit.
So, why did protesters think Stroud voted Remain in 2016, and did they think the district would do so again?
When we put this to Gill Lloyd, who chairs Glostays, he praised the campaign led by Neil Carmichael, Stroud’s pro-EU Conservative MP at the time of the referendum.
And, once we got to London, it turned out Mr Carmichael was actually at the march.
“I tried to lead from the front during the referendum, and never shied away from praising Europe - to some extent I think that made a difference,” he later told the
.
Others, like Gareth from Stroud, argued it was less about the campaign and more about the district's ethos.
"The general attitude of Stroud people is that we're inclusive - just look at the welcome we've given to Syrian refugees."
All of the Glostays activists we spoke to, however, were confident Stroud would opt for Remain, or an option close to that, in a second vote.
What do you think? Should there be another vote? Would Stroud vote Remain again? Email your thoughts to alex.clark@newsquest.co.uk

item.body:
These are the first pictures of a cowardly drug dealer who blasted a rival with a shotgun in front of terrified Christmas shoppers.
 
Jamie Bridge fired at Christopher Jopson with a sawn-off shotgun in Southport town centre at lunchtime on December 21 last year.
 
 The 22-year-old, of Wyresdale Road, Aintree, also hit bus driver Lee Armstrong , as parents and children watched on in disbelief. 
 
Bridge was released from a two-year jail sentence for dealing heroin and cocaine and possessing a blade in public, in February 2017.
 
In pictures uploaded to Facebook in 2016, he is seen surrounded by posters of nude women on the walls and stacks of toiletries in a narrow room with two bunk beds.
 
 Drug dealer who shot rival in head is guilty of attempted murder in town centre 
 
 
 
In another image, Bridge, wearing a Nike Air Max t-shirt, is seen raising his middle finger in between two small bunk beds and a wall covered with drawings of scrambler bikes.
 
His victim Jopson, had 30 pellets removed from the back of his head, while Mr Armstrong, 32, suffered wounds to his head and left shoulder.
 
Bridge admitted wounding Jopson, 26, with intent to cause grievous bodily harm, but denied attempted murder in a three-day trial.
 
 
 
He also admitted wounding Mr Armstrong, plus possessing a firearm with intent to both endanger life and to cause fear of violence.
 
Bridge claimed he only wanted "to put him in hospital" after Jopson threatened him with guns and robbed and stabbed his underling.
 
But a jury found the dad-of-one guilty by a majority of 10 to 2 this afternoon, after three hours of deliberation at Liverpool Crown Court.
 
CCTV footage showed the masked gunman chase and fire at Jopson, in the middle of the road in Eastbank Street, at around 12.27pm.
 
Arriva worker Mr Armstrong had just waved 15 people onto a bus when he heard "a loud bang and cracking noise" and suddenly felt pain.
 
 
 
The victim said: "I touched my head and realised I was bleeding. There were loads of people on the pavement all standing frozen."
 
Henry Riding, prosecuting, said the pellets shattered the glass in a bus stop outside a Coral bookmakers, as Jopson "fled for his life".
 
Gunman who shot man in head in front of shoppers denies attempted murder 
A schoolgirl witness told the jury the gunman pointed the weapon at Jopson's upper back, while her friend said he shouted "get here".
 
Micheal Gibbons, who pushed his "terrified" four-year-old son out of harm's way, said he saw the gunman stop, take aim and fire.
 
He said: "In my opinion the shooter was aiming to hit the first male at close range and he didn’t care who else was around."
 
Mr Riding said: “Chasing after a man - no doubt fleeing for his life - and blasting him in the back of the head from a distance of no less than 10 metres is about as good as evidence as you can get of intention to kill."
 
He suggested Bridge - who police identified on earlier clips that day when he wasn't disguised - then hid at his girlfriend Julia Minicka's flat.
 
When arrested in January, he denied any involvement, then repeated his lies in a second interview, after CCTV evidence was recovered.
 
 
Officers called to the scene found Jopson sitting on a chair, outside Thorntons in Chapel Street, holding a tea towel to his head.
 
PC Michael Tague said he was "quite dismissive" when offered first aid, "surprisingly relaxed" and "didn’t appear to be shaken at all".
 
Jopson initially refused to give a statement, but told police he was shot by a man nicknamed "Wolfie", who had a Polish girlfriend, Julia.
 
He said he could not think of any reason why "Wolfie" would want to shoot him, telling officers: "I don’t have any issues with anyone."
 
Bridge said he and Jopson both dealt cannabis but Jopson was "jealous" of his profits and threatened him, Miss Minicka and his mum.
 
Bridge said: “He said if I didn't stop selling drugs in the Southport area he will blow her head off.”
 
He said he heard Jopson "cocking" a gun on the phone and he came to Miss Minicka's flat with other men, asked for him and kicked the door.
 
Bridge said Jopson worked with dealers who previously forced him to sell Class A drugs and who he fell out with when jailed.
 
He said he and Miss Minicka moved into the town's Vincent Hotel on December 19 and 20, after a friend, Simon Dunn, was stabbed.
 
Bridge said Dunn's phone rang him at 1.15am on December 15, but it was Jopson, who said "you’re not out tonight are you?" and hung up.
 
He said he found out Jopson stabbed Dunn and because of his "anger", got a gun off a friend on December 21, “just to hurt him”.
 
Bridge said he had it for "protection", adding: "It was either going to be me dead or... It was either going to go one way or the other.”
 
He claimed he tried to get close to Jopson “so I didn’t injure no-one else around him”, then "aimed at his leg".
 
 
Asked about injuring Mr Armstrong, he said: "I feel sorry for him and his family. I regret it every day of me life."
 
Bridge accepted telling "a pack of lies" to police and swearing on his son’s life when denying being involved.
 
Charles Lander, defending, asked: "Did you intend to kill Mr Jopson that day?" "No," he replied.
 
Mr Riding asked what he meant by “it was either going to me dead or..." and it going "one way or the other”.
 
Bridge said he meant injured - not dead - and denied having a "shoot to kill policy".
 
 Attempted murder accused 'chased victim down street and fired shotgun at his head in front of Christmas shoppers' 
 
He said: "If I wanted to kill him I would have got up close to him and done it properly.”
 
Bridge, who claimed Jopson tried to chat up Miss Minicka, said he didn't want to kill him and spend his life in prison.
 
But he accepted if Jopson chased him and fired at him with a shotgun, he would think he was trying to kill him.
 
He agreed he had "ready access" to the weapon and "the bottle" to shoot someone, but said he did not aim at Jopson's head.
 
Bridge, who confessed to destroying his mobile phone, said: “I fired it as I was running... I aimed for the bottom half of his body.”
 
He said Jopson was "the one who caused all this" and the shooting was justified by his threats and stabbing Mr Dunn.
 
Bridge confirmed he offered to have the gun handed into police, in exchange for the attempted murder charge being dropped.
 
 
The dealer said: "I’m sorry for the people I affected, but I’m not sorry for what I did to Jopson.”
 
He accepted Dunn was a "smackhead" who dealt cannabis for him and Jopson "shivved" and "taxed" him, taking £400 meant for him.
 
Bridge denied it was “a drugs turf war over who controls Southport” but accepted it was “an escalating war between rival drug dealers”.
 
He said Jopson previously attacked Dunn with a hammer and he got a shotgun to "teach him a lesson", wanting “to put him in hospital”.
 
Bridge said he collected the gun from Victoria Park, but it was a "coincidence" he saw Jopson in a Betfred bookmakers and wasn't tipped off.
 
He said Jopson ducked when he chased and shot at him, which is why he got him in the head, despite aiming for his leg.
 
The jury heard Merseyside Police received five reports in 2017 stating Jopson may have been in possession of a firearm.
 
Mr Lander said these allegations "had not been investigated or substantiated by the police".
 
A police log recorded Dunn received four puncture wounds when he was stabbed and reported £400 in cash and a bicycle stolen.
 
Mr Lander said Jopson's previous convictions include four assaults, possessing a bladed article and affray.
 
He argued what his client did was "appalling" and "disgraceful", but jurors could not be sure he intended to kill Jopson.
 
However, Mr Riding said "the town wasn't big enough for the both of them" and "Mr Bridge was ready to take this war to Mr Jopson”.
 
He said in a scene in the 1971 Dirty Harry film, Clint Eastwood's character, Inspector Callahan, is grilled over shooting an alleged rapist.
 
Mr Riding said Insp Callahan says "when a naked man is chasing a woman through an alley with a butcher knife and a hard-on, I figure he isn’t out collecting for the Red Cross," to which the mayor replies: "I think he’s got a point."
 
Mr Riding said: “Sometimes the evidence speaks for itself.”
 
Judge Denis Watson, QC, said Bridge will be sentenced tomorrow and remanded him in custody.

item.body:
Arsenal fans are all saying the same thing after Joel Campbell's latest performance for Costa Rica at the World Cup - 'give him some game time Unai!'
 
The 25-year-old put in an impressive performance out wide for his country as they got their first point of Russia 2018 thanks to a 2-2 draw with Switzerland, despite having already been out of the tournament before the game started. 
 
They went behind twice, but Campbell won his side a penalty that Bryan Ruiz put away via the back of the Switzerland keeper, but it was his skill on the ball and directness that had social media users Tweeting about after the game. 
 
Campbell has spent most of his time at Arsenal out on loan, spending last season out in Spain with La Liga side Real Betis, with the spell before that coming in Portugal at Sporting. 
 
 
 
 
He's likely to return to north London to report for pre-season training after having a break now that his World Cup adventure is over, despite not having feature for them for over two years. 
 
 Stephan Lichtsteiner to miss Switzerland's Round of 16 tie with Sweden after second booking 
 
But now with new boss Unai Emery in charge of the Gunners, he's got the opportunity to stake a claim in the Arsenal team for next season with a fresh slate, something he's not had with Arsene Wenger's stewardship of the side.
 
Here's what fans on Twitter had to say after his most recent performance.

item.description: A 20-year-old man has died from stab wounds after a fight involving baseball bats.
item.body:
A 20-year-old man has died from stab wounds after a fight involving baseball bats.
Police launched a murder investigation today (June 27) after they were called at 6.33pm to reports of an “altercation” in Cavendish Road, Edmonton.
Upon arrival they discovered a 20-year-old man with stab wounds who died at the scene at 7.20pm.
Police, the London Ambulance Service and the Air Ambulance attended, and a crime scene is now in place with additional scenes at Brettenham Road and Cameron Close.
Police enquiries are underway to identify and locate the man’s next of kin and a post mortem will be conducted in due course.
No arrests have been made and the motive is still unknown.
Enfield Police and the Homicide and Major Crime Command are appealing for anyone who witnessed this incident to call 101 quoting reference number 6485/27JUN.

item.description: THIS is the terrifying moment masked men brandishing an axe and a crowbar broke into a shop in Maguiresbridge in the early hours of Wednesday…
item.body:
THIS is the terrifying moment masked men brandishing an axe and a crowbar broke into a shop in Maguiresbridge in the early hours of Wednesday morning.
The men gained entry to Frazer’s One Stop Shop in the village where they knocked over some of the displays before leaving the ATM “in bits” and escaping without anything.
Footage, seen by The Impartial Reporter, shows how the men, who were all wearing dark clothing, spent less than 10 minutes at the premises, owned by businessman Adrian Frazer.
It shows how the men arrived at the forecourt in a Subaru Outback at about 1.28am and quickly began to push the front door. Then they suddenly left the scene and four minutes later returned with one of the them taking an axe out of the vehicle and using it to gain entry.
While inside the shop they ransacked shelves of magazines and pastries before attempting to remove the ATM. But they were unable to access it and left empty handed at 1.38am.
Speaking at the scene yesterday (Wednesday) Mr. Frazer, who has owned the shop for eight years, said the incident had caused “disruption to the customer and the staff.”
“As a businessman you always have to worry and we will have to step up our security,” he said.
Manager Darren McManus, who was alerted to the break in as soon as it occurred, said he was “shocked.”
“It is not something that happens too often in a small community like ours, you never expect that type of thing to go on in this area.
“They didn’t take anything as far as we can see, they wrecked the front of the ATM, ransacked part of the shop and the ATM is in bits. They damaged the front of the door and damaged a few stands but that was about it.
“We will now leave it with the police to investigate,” he said.
Part of the shop was sealed off yesterday as detectives commenced their investigation.
Detectives are appealing for information and witnesses following the report of the attempted theft.
In a statement, Detective Inspector Trevor Stevenson said: “We received a report at approximately 1.50am that three men had forced entry to a shop in the Main Street area, using an axe,” he said.
“Damage was caused to an internal ATM machine. However, it was reported the men left empty handed.”
Detective Stevenson said he is appealing to anyone who was in the area and saw any suspicious activity, or anyone who knows anything about this incident, to contact police at Enniskillen on number 101 quoting reference 112 of 20/061/18.

item.body:
Areas across Cardiff will be targeted in a 'blitz' of deep cleaning this summer.
 
A council team will be in wards across the city digging out silt and debris from between the pavement and the roads, clearing gullies and drains, litter picking, cutting back overgrowth in lanes as well as any other work that is required in what's known as 'blitz' operations.
 
Community litter picks have also been organised as part of the council's Love Where You Live Campaign - which aims to promote civic pride and that littering and fly-tipping isn’t acceptable.
 
 Where will the deep cleans be happening? 
 
The council's deep-cleaning 'blitz' operations are taking place in parts of Pontprennau and Pentwyn this week, before moving to parts of Cathays and Plasnewydd on July 2 until July 6.
 
Areas of the following wards will then receive deep clean this summer:
 
 
 July 9 – July 13: Ely and Fairwater 
 July 16– July 20: Caerau and Canton 
 July 23 – July 27: Butetown and Grangetown 
 July 30 – August 24: Cardiff’s parks. 
 
 Where and when will the litter picks be? 
 
Community litter picks have been organised from between 10am and 11.30am at the following locations:
 
 
 June 29: Countisbury Avenue, Llanrumney 
 July 2: Cathays Library, Cathays 
 July 4: Albany Primary School, Plasnewydd 
 July 9: Fairwater Leisure Centre, Fairwater 
 July 13: Ely & Caerau Hub, Ely 
 July 18: Jubilee Recreation Ground, Canton 
 July 20: Roundwood, Pentwyn 
 July 23: Canal Park, Butetown 
 July 25: The Marl, Butetown 
 July 26: Eastern Leisure Centre, Llanrumney 
 July 27: Fairwater Green, Fairwater 
 
Councillor Michael Michael, Cardiff council's cabinet member for clean streets and recycling, said: "The uptake from the community with this campaign has been superb and we now have 13 community groups set up across the city. They all do an excellent job supporting the council to try to keep communities clean and tidy and I would like to thank them all for their efforts.
 
“We need to create a sense of pride in our communities, so that people understand that throwing litter on the floor or fly tipping in back lanes isn’t acceptable. Initially the campaign focussed on the inner more densely populated areas, where this work is most needed but I am pleased to report that all wards across the city will now receive this service."
 
The council has recently announced it will use infrared cameras and spot fines of £400 in its battle against fly tippers.
 
A survey asking for their views on fly tipping has also been launched.

item.body:
A heterosexual couple fighting a law which prevents them entering into a civil partnership have called on the Government to "act with urgency" after winning a legal battle at the UK's highest court.
 
Following a declaration by the Supreme Court that the current legislation is "incompatible" with human rights laws, Rebecca Steinfeld and Charles Keidan described being "elated".
 
Speaking outside court after Wednesday's ruling, Ms Steinfeld, 37, said: "Today we are a step closer to opening civil partnerships to all, a measure that would be fair, popular and good for families and children across the country."
 
Mr Keidan, 41, said there was now only one option - "to extend civil partnerships to all".
 
He said it was hoped the Government would now "act with urgency" for the sake of thousands of couples across the country.
 
The couple, who have two young daughters and live in Hammersmith, west London, are currently prevented from having a legal union through the route of civil partnership because the Civil Partnership Act 2004 says only same-sex couples are eligible.
 
What happened? 
 
Five Supreme Court justices, including the court's president Lady Hale, granted a declaration that, in precluding a different sex couple from entering into a civil partnership, the Act was "incompatible" with European human rights laws on discrimination and the right to a private and family life.
 
While granting the declaration, the court pointed out that the Government was not "obliged" to do anything as the result of its decision on incompatibility.
 
Lord Kerr, explaining the decision, said the Government "does not seek to justify the difference in treatment between same-sex and different sex couples".
 
He added: "To the contrary, it accepts that the difference cannot be justified."
 
What the Government sought was "tolerance of the discrimination while it sorts out how to deal with it".
 
He concluded: "That cannot be characterised as a legitimate aim."
 
What is a civil partnership? 
A civil partnership, which was created by the Civil Partnership Act 2004, defined civil partnerships as a ‘relationship between two people of the same sex’.
 
However, at this morning’s hearing, the court said the act is incompatible with the European Convention on Human Rights, because it does not apply to heterosexual couples.
 
So can heterosexual couples now enter into a civil partnership? 
  Not yet. 
 
That would require an act of Parliament, but the ruling certainly puts pressure on the government to extend the right to civil partnerships to all.
 
 Firefighters call in army to tackle raging Saddleworth Moor fire 
 
What is the difference between civil partnership and marriage? 
  There are some small differences relating to the ceremonies; a civil partnership becomes official when the second civil partner signs a particular legal document, while marriages aren’t recognised by law until the couple say their vows. 
 
Also, civil partnership ceremonies aren’t religious and can’t be treated as such.
 
  Civil partnerships can’t be ended on the grounds of adultery (at present, given that civil partnership is only available to same sex couples and the definition of adultery specifies that it takes place between a man and a woman). 
 
Marriages, however, can.
 
  Those in civil partnerships should also be aware that, when travelling or living abroad, the union is often not legally recognised in the same way that marriage is. 
 
  However, the legal rights of those involved are actually exactly the same in many areas, such as child maintenance, tenancy rights, social security, inheritance tax, full life insurance recognition, next of kin rights, and acquiring parental responsibility. 
 
What did Rebecca and Charles argue? 
Rebecca Steinfeld and Charles Keidan successfully argued that the introduction of the Marriage (Same Sex Couples) Act 2013 meant that gay couples could choose one of two ways to have their relationship recognised in English law, while heterosexual couples could only marry.
 
That inequality, according to the Supreme Court, amounted to discrimination.
 
How did Lord Kerr react? 
 
Lord Kerr said it was "salutary to recall that a declaration of incompatibility does not oblige the Government or Parliament to do anything".
 
During a hearing in May, the couple's barrister, Karon Monaghan QC, told the Supreme Court that they have "deep-rooted and genuine ideological objections to marriage" and are "not alone" in their views.
 
She said matrimony was "historically heteronormative and patriarchal" and the couple's objections were "not frivolous".
 
Ms Monaghan added: "These are important issues, no small matters, and they are serious for my clients because they cannot marry conformable with their conscience and that should weigh very heavily indeed."
 
The Supreme Court justices unanimously allowed an appeal by the couple against a Court of Appeal decision which went against them in February last year.
 
The Court of Appeal had agreed that they had established a potential violation of Article 14 of the European Convention on Human Rights, which relates to discrimination, taken with Article 8, which refers to respect for private and family life.
 
But, by a majority of two to one, the judges said the interference was justified by the Government's policy of "wait and evaluate".
 
The Government said it was decided, after public consultations and debate in Parliament, not to extend civil partnerships to opposite-sex couples, abolish them or phase them out at that stage.
 
The aim was to see how extending marriage to same-sex couples impacted on civil partnerships before making a final decision which, if reversed in a few years, would be disruptive, unnecessary and extremely expensive.
 
Mr Keidan, a magazine editor, said outside court: "There are 3.3 million cohabiting couples in this country, the fastest growing family type.
 
"Many want legal recognition and financial protection, but cannot have it because they are not married and because the choice of a civil partnership is not open to them.
 
"The law needs to catch up with the reality of family life in Britain in 2018."

item.description: All services from the high level this evening were called off due to "multiple points failures" near the station.
item.body: Passengers have been facing travel disruption in hot weather after all trains from Glasgow Central high level were cancelled due to "multiple points failures" near the station. ScotRail said it was unable to run trains in or out of the high level station on Wednesday evening, although trains from the low level platforms were not affected. ScotRail said that where possible it was starting and terminating trains at Paisley and Motherwell and customers could use their tickets on some bus services to reach their destinations. Network Rail said that engineers were on site and the cause of the points failure was under investigation. Earlier on Wednesday afternoon Scotrail tweeted: "Due to the high temperatures today, all routes going in / out of Glasgow Central are severely disrupted. "Please use alternative travel where possible, really sorry if you're affected by this today." Temperatures reached 29.2C in Glasgow as Scotland enjoyed the hottest day of the year so far. A ScotRail Alliance spokesman said: "We sincerely apologise to customers affected by this disruption and completely understand their frustration when these things happen.
item.title: Glasgow Central trains cancelled as hot weather causes railway travel chaos

THIS was the scene last Wednesday moments after a car collided with a wall outside a house in Lisnaskea.
It’s understood the Northern Ireland Ambulance Service received a 999 call at around 9.37am following reports of a one car road traffic collision on Lisnagole Road.
An ambulance was dispatched to the scene.
Following initial assessment and treatment, one patient was transported to South West Acute Hospital, said a spokeswoman for the Northern Ireland Ambulance Service.

item.description: TWO sisters who may be the oldest surviving twins from Yorkshire were overjoyed to be reunited on their 95th birthday.
item.body: TWO sisters who may be the oldest surviving twins from Yorkshire were overjoyed to be reunited on their 95th birthday. Muriel Stancliffe and twin sister Lily Poolman met for the first time in more than three years tonight (Weds June 27) before a party with family and friends at the Devon pub in Crossgates, Leeds,. The twin sisters, who grew up in East End Park, Leeds, were inseparable as children and young adults and trained as hairdressers together at Woodhouse Lane College. They both joined the Women’s Land Army as 19-year-olds during the Second World War in 1942. It was the only way the two sisters could help the war effort and stay together after Women’s Land Army bosses agreed not to split them up. They worked on farms in Wiltshire for four years before working together as hairdressers in Leeds. Lily, who has six great-great grandchildren, met her late husband Reg in Wiltshire and the couple later ran a farm in Swindon area, while Muriel stayed in Leeds. Muriel, whose husband Joseph died aged 52 in 1973, has three great-grandchildren. Muriel said she felt stomach pains and could not sleep when Lily was giving birth to her first child Carol, now aged 71. Muriel, who later worked as a sales assistant at Woolworths in Crossgates, said after the party: “It was lovely to see her again, we were delighted.” Lily said: “I was thrilled to see her – I just wanted to hug her.” Muriel’s granddaughter Jane Stancliffe, 37, said: “They are very close. They used to spend a lot of time together and still speak to each other all the time. “Grandma used to travel to Swindon a lot but she has been unable to travel more recently due to mobility issues.” Jane said the sisters’ mother Ethel lived to 104, adding: “They are up there with the oldest surviving twins in the UK.
item.title: Leeds twin sisters reunited on 95th birthday

item.description: Heather Knight collected the award at Buckingham Palace
item.body: Winner of The Herald’s Sports Personality of the Year prize, Heather, 27, who was raised in Plymouth and honed her cricketing skills in Plymstock, was honoured for services to cricket after leading England to beat India in the final to win the 2017 World Cup and helping change women’s cricket forever. Her 364 runs at an average of 45, including a century against Pakistan, were central to England’s success. After collecting her award from the Prince of Wales at Buckingham Palace, she said: “For us to sell out Lord’s was something I never thought would happen and something like 200 million people watched us on telly which was completely unheard of. “There was a moment when we were singing the national anthem in that world cup final when the whole crowd was with us and Eileen Whelan (former English Test cricketer) who was 105 years old was ringing the five-minute bell. “There was Rachael Heyhoe Flint (the former England women’s cricket captain) who obviously fought for us to play at Lord’s, I was getting quite emotional and thinking what a big day it was for the sport and the women who played before us. “To be allowed to play at Lord’s, to sell it out and to win on home soil was the perfect story really.” Knight, who plays club cricket for Plymstock in the Devon Cricket League, was among Wisden’s Cricketers of the Year. Of her visit to Buckingham Palace for the glittery honours ceremony, she said: “It is a bit strange putting the heels on. We do not often get the heels out on tours in cricket. “It is nice to get outside the cricket bubble and have a day off.” She said it was also great to be able to share the day with her father Mike, mother Beccy and brother Stephen because “it is also an award for them for all the support they have given me and the trials and tribulations I have put them through”. Also collecting an honour at the palace yesterday was Bee Gee Barry Gibb, who was made a Knight by the Prince of Wales, and chef Rick Stein, who was made a CBE
item.title: Plymouth's World Cup-winning cricket captain collects her OBE
