item.body:
Brazil booked their place in the last 16 of the World Cup with a hard-fought 2-0 win against Serbia in Moscow this evening (Wednesday).
 
It was a game that didn't really get going in the first half, with chances few and far between at both ends.
 
Neymar had the best opportunity of the first half hour for Brazil, but he saw his effort saved well by Vladimir Stojkovic.
 
But the South Americans did make the breakthrough on 35 minutes, with former Spurs man Paulinho making a run from midfield to latch onto Philippe Coutinho's incisive pass, before lifting the ball over the top of Stojkovic for the opener.
 
 World Cup player ratings: Kante and Hazard in top form but Willian is having a mixed time 
 
 
 
Serbia had chances to equalise early on in the second half as they got on top, with Aleksandar Mitrovic guilty of missing the best of them, heading straight at Thiago Silva after Brazil goalkeeper Alisson parried a cross into his path.
 
And Brazil made them pay midway through the second half as Thiago Silva rose highest to head home Neymar's inswinging corner.
 
Serbia rarely threatened thereafter as Brazil comfortably saw out the game to go through as Group E winners.
 
Here's how we rated the players from both sides, below.
 
SERBIA 
 
  
Goalkeeper - Vladimir Stojkovic 
Made a superb stop to deny Neymar as he looked to break the deadlock, getting a firm hand to palm his shot away. Also saved with his feet to deny Neymar in the second half, but may feel he could have done better with Brazil's opener. 6
 
Right-back - Antonio Rukavina 
Did alright for the most part against the test provided by Neymar on Brazil's left, but was beaten on a few occasions down his side. 5
 
Centre-back - Nikola Milenkovic 
Made a few important interceptions and clearances in defence. But was beaten in the air for Brazil's second goal. 5
 
Centre-back - Milos Veljkovic 
Helped to contain the forward threat of Jesus, Neymar and Willian, but was found wanting with the ball over the top for Paulinho's goal. 5
 
Left-back - Aleksandar Kolarov 
 
Picked out by the ITV pundits as being at fault for failing to come inside to track Paulinho's run for Brazil's opening goal. And had a relatively poor game by his standards. 4
 
Centre midfielder - Nemanja Matic 
A typical display from the midfielder, who got his foot in when necessary. His influence faded in the second half though and he was booked for fouling Gabriel Jesus. 5
 
 Some Crystal Palace fans are saying the same thing as Serbia fall behind against Brazil 
 
Centre midfielder - Sergej Milinkovic-Savic 
Playing in a deeper role alongside Matic, he was not really given the freedom to excel going forward, particularly in the first half. He showed some flashes of his ability in the second half, but this was not his best game. 6
 
Attacking midfielder - Adem Ljajic 
The Torino man was brought into the side for this decisive game, with Mladen Krstajic opting for more attack-minded personnel in a must-win game for the Serbians. He looked to get on the ball when possible, and put a couple of dangerous balls into the box, but was booked for a cynical foul on Neymar. 7
 
Right winger - Dusan Tadic 
 
On the day a deal was announced for him to join Ajax from Southampton, he showed glimpses of his creativity and what the Saints will miss. He had a few good moments in the game, but not enough of them. 6 
 
Left winger - Filip Kostic 
Provided an outlet for Serbia on the left wing and caused Fagner problems, particularly in the first half. He also showed his strength and ability on the ball at times, but faded before being substituted. 7
 
Striker - Aleksandar Mitrovic 
 
Was a handful for the Brazilian defenders, with his physical presence causing some problems, but he wasn't used enough by Serbia as they failed to really make the most of his threat. He still had Serbia's best opportunity, but somehow missed when he really should have scored. 6
 
World Cup fans realise what Fulham already knew about Newcastle striker Aleksandr Mitrovic
 
Substitutes: 
Andrija Zivkovic (on for Ljajic, 75) 
Brought on as Serbia tried to chase the game, but failed to have much of an impact. 5
 
Nemanja Radonjic (on for Kostic, 82) 
Brought on for the final eight minutes of normal time, but didn't really influence the game. 5
 
Luka Jovic (on for Mitrovic, 89)
 
Not enough time to make an impact. 5
 
Brazil 
 
Goalkeeper: Alisson
 
Didn't have too much to do in the Brazil goal as Serbia failed to really test him, but almost gifted Serbia an equaliser as he parried a cross straight into Mitrovic's path, only for the striker to head straight at Thiago Silva. 5
 
Right-back: Fagner 
 
Struggled at times against Kostic, conceding a number of free kicks as Serbia got some joy down his side. 4
 
Centre-back: Thiago Silva
 
 
Was superb at the back for Brazil and put his body on the line at times to make some crucial blocks, including one to deny Mitrovic. He capped off his performance with the second goal midway through the second half. 8
 
Centre-back: Miranda 
 
Had his hands full with Mitrovic, but was solid enough to help Brazil keep a clean sheet. 7
 
Left-back: Marcelo 
 
Looked uncomfortable early on and did not make it past ten minutes, as he was substituted for Filipe Luis. 5
 
 
 
Centre midfielder: Casemiro 
 
Was relatively quiet throughout the game, and was only really notable for a wild shot from distance that flew high over the bar. 5
 
Centre midfielder: Paulinho 
 
Scored the opening goal after a fine burst from midfield, showing composure to lift the ball over the advancing Stojkovic. He faded in the second half, before being substituted. 7
 
Centre midfielder: Philippe Coutinho 
 
Rarely gave the ball away and provided a good link between midfield and attack. Also provided the assist for Paulinho with a superbly weighted pass to split the Serbia defence open. 8
 
Forward: Willian
 
 
Was better than his last display, but was still wasteful at times when in a good position. Has not recreated the form he has shown at times for Chelsea. 6
 
 Brazil 2-0 Costa Rica player ratings: Willian disappoints as Coutinho saves the day 
 
Striker: Gabriel Jesus
 
Tried to get involved, but didn't really have any clear cut opportunities. Still worked hard up top and contributed to the victory. 6
 
Forward: Neymar
 
Kept quiet in the first half by Serbia, and failed to make the most of a couple of good positions. He tried a couple of flicks and tricks, and put in the corner for Thiago Silva's goal, but still needs to do more at this tournament to justify the hype around him. 6
 
Substitutes - 
Filipe Luis (on for Marcelo, 10) 
 
The former Chelsea man was introduced into the fray early on, with Marcelo unable to carry on. He was comfortable enough at left-back without doing anything spectacular. 6
 
Fernandinho (on for Paulinho, 66)
 
Came on to shore up things for Brazil after an early second half wobble. And Brazil looked more comfortable after his introduction. Also showed his ability on the ball. 7
 
Renato Augusto (on for Coutinho, 80) 
 
Given a run out for the final ten minutes as Coutinho was given a rest. 5

item.body:
A chemical spill sparked a ‘hazmat’ incident in Elland after a stolen tanker was dumped on a public road.
 
Specialists hazardous materials officers from West Yorkshire Fire and Rescue Service were mobilised after a concerned member of the public noticed a chemical tanker leaking on Old Power Way at Lowfields.
 
Firefighters from Rastrick and Dewsbury were also called to the incident, at about 12:40pm yesterday (Tuesday).
 
They discovered the tanker contained a flammable liquid that was pharmaceutical waste, some of which had spilled out on the road.
 
 
West Yorkshire Police was called and it was discovered the vehicle had been taken from South Yorkshire.
 
The owners of the tanker were contacted and they quickly travelled to Elland to retrieve the vehicle.
 
A specialist waste contractor was brought in to clean the hazardous fluid off the road.
 
Nobody was harmed by the spillage.
 
 Listen: Blundering Kirklees Council worker accidentally left resident a rude voicemail 
 
West Yorkshire Police told the Examiner it had not actively been involved in the incident.
 
South Yorkshire Police has been approached for comment but has so far not released any details.
item.title: Chemical spill sparks 'hazmat' incident after stolen tanker dumped on street

item.body:
There was penalty drama as Costa Rica managed to get a 2-2 draw with Switzerland and their first points of the tournament.
 
Costa Rica were unlucky not to break the deadlock - they hit the post first and then a Daniel Colindres piledriver crashed against the crossbar.
 
Switzerland took the lead despite being under the cosh somewhat in the opening period, and on the half hour mark Stephan Lichtsteiner found Breel Embolo, who nodded it back to Blerim Dzemaili to smash home.
 
The second half started in the same form, with Costa Rica threatening early on before Switzerland themselves started to out efforts on goal, with Embolo coming close.
 
But Costa Rica got their first goal of the World Cup when Watson rose highest from corner to nod home and get his country level.
 
The Swiss nearly found themselves ahead when substitute Josip Drmic nodded an Embolo cross against the crossbar with 12 minutes left in the tie.
 
But he got his goal with just three minutes remaining when he connected with a cross on the edge of the box and slotted home.
 
Costa Rica then thought they had got themselves a penalty just a minute later, but VAR intervened as Bryan Ruiz was ruled out for offside.
 
However, they managed to get themselves another penalty, with Ruiz smashing the crossbar before the ball bounced back, hit Sommer and went into the net.
 
 South Korea 2-0 Germany player ratings: Son scores to send Ozil crashing out of the World Cup 
 
Switzerland  
Goalkeeper: Yann Sommer - 7
 
Stunning save within five minutes to deny Costa Rica, tipping the header onto the post. Looked uncomfortable coming for crosses but an otherwise good display.
 
Right back: Stephan Lichtsteiner - 8
 
Produced a wonderful cross for the opening goal to find Embolo. Had a solid game at right back and caused Costa Rica problems going forward.
 
Centre back: Fabian Schar - 6
 
Decent game at the back for Schar who marshaled his backline well as Costa Rica looked to find more goals.
 
Centre back: Manuel Akanji - 7
 
Solid game from the central defender, who at 22 showed maturity beyond his years in the heart of the Swiss defence. Should've done better when marking his man at the corner that Costa Rica scored from.
 
 
 
 
Left back: Ricardo Rodriguez - 6
 
Looked better going forward than he did defensively as he struggled to contain Colindres, who enjoyed far too much time out on his wing.
 
Defensive midfielder: Granit Xhaka - 7
 
Got on the ball in midfield and was Switzerland's link between defence and attack. Put himself about as he tried to break up the Costa Rican attacks.
 
Defensive midfielder: Valon Behrami - 6
 
Decent showing in the defensive midfield role without ever really exceeding expectations for Switzerland. Subbed off at 60, probably with the fact he was at risk of missing the next round on the manager's mind.
 
Attacking midfielder: Xherdan Shaqiri - 7
 
Looked in the mood early on, full of skill and willing to attack the left back. Was the main man in the second half as he got on the ball and looked to make things happen for his country.
 
Attacking midfielder: Blerim Dzemaili - 7
 
Demonstrated a good reading of the game to be waiting in the middle of the box to get his goal. Seemed to arrive in the right places at the right time.
 
 
 
 
Attacking midfielder: Breel Embolo - 8
 
Showed good awareness to nod his header back to Dzemaili for the opening goal. Had a few chances in the second half as he proved to be a thorn in the side of the Costa Rican defence.
 
Forward: Mario Gavranovic - 5
 
Largely anonymous performance from the forward, who didn't really get a chance to put his mark on the game, Was subbed off on the 68th minute.
 
Subsitutes: 
Denis Zakaria (Valon Behrami 59') - 5
 
Did very little in the midfield after coming on for Behrami.
 
Josip Drmic (Mario Gavranovic 68') - 8
 
Unlucky not to get himself a goal when he rose well to connect with a good Embolo cross with 12 minutes left. Really good finish to get his goal from the edge of the box. Good sub from the boss.
 
Michael Lang (Xherdan Shaqiri 80') - 5
 
Didn't have enough time to have a say on proceedings.

Costa Rica  
Goalkeeper: Keylor Navas - 6
 
Didn't have too much to do but made a few decent saves, while his communication and distribution was good.
 
Left back: Kendall Watson - 7
 
Showed great strength to rise highest from the corner, holding off the challenge of Akanji to nod home the goal for Costa Rica.
 
Centre back: Giancarlo Gonzalez - 6
 
Had a difficult start to the game but got to terms with Costa Rica's attacking players more as the game went on.
 
Right back: Johnny Acosta - 7
 
Showed some nice displays of defensive work during the game and looked to use his wing backs well.
 
 
 
 
Left midfielder: Bryan Oviedo - 7
 
Really struggled with Shaqiri this evening as the Swiss man's skill caused Oviedo problem after problem. Attacked well down his flank and looked one of the ones to make something happen.
 
Central midfielder: David Guzman - 7
 
Was combative in the middle of the park as he looked to put himself about and disrupt Switzerland when they were in possession. Released some nice passes for his front men to thrive off
 
Central midfielder: Celso Borges - 6
 
Average performance in the middle of the park from Borges. Put in a few nice touches.
 
Right midfielder: Cristian Gamboa - 6
 
Had a decent performance down the right and caused Switzerland some problems from time to time.
 
Left forward: Bryan Ruiz - 5
 
Cruised through the game without really do much for his side. Struggled to get on the ball much and was largely ineffective.
 
 
 
Right forward: Joel Campbell - 7
 
Started the game brightly and caused problems down the right flank. Got himself the assist with a lovely taken corner. Was a bit quieter as the game wore on but he'll be pleased with his performance.
 
 
 
 
Central Forward: Daniel Colindres - 7
 
Capitalised on Shaqiri giving the ball away cheaply and unleashed a wonderful effort that crashed off the bar. Fizzled out as the second half wore on.

No time to affect the game.

Had no time to affect the game.

item.body:
Which Cambridge organisations have been the most influential over the last 130 years? We're launching a search for the brightest and best, and need your help.
 
This year the News is marking its 130th birthday, and as part of the celebrations we want to recognise 130 local businesses that have made a positive impact on the region over that period – whether through their contribution to the local economy, their outstanding customer service or simply because they are just representative of the area.
 
Nominations are open now for the event, which is sponsored by HSBC and Marshall Group, and the 130 chosen businesses will be profiled in the News later this year.
 
 
  
   
    
    
   
  
 
News editor in chief David Bartlett said: "Cambridge is a special place because of its people and the bright minds that launch businesses, run companies, and innovate here.
 
"We wanted to do something to celebrate the 130th anniversary of Cambridge News as a business that has been at the heart of the community since 1888.
 
 
 
 
"We may be one of the oldest businesses in the city, but we want to celebrate the best of Cambridge and those that have made an impact over that period."I'm really looking forward to celebrating all those businesses at a special event at Queens' College, Cambridge in October."
 
Cambridge is, of course, well-known as a world leader in the fields of technology and life sciences, but the region's business scene encompasses many other sectors, and includes outstanding companies ranging from sole traders and start-ups to corporations with a global footprint.
 
Jason Smithers, area director at HSBC, said: “We are delighted to sponsor the search for Cambridge’s 130 most Influential Businesses. HSBC have been part of the Cambridge business community for over 100 years and its core strengths in innovation and international focus very much match those of Cambridge businesses. ”
 
The nomination period is open now, and will run until September. The winners will be invited to a special networking event, which is being held at Queens' College on Wednesday, October 17.
 
To make a nomination, fill in the form below:
 
Enter Cambridge's Most Influential businesses
item.title: The search is on for Cambridge's most influential businesses

item.description: An expert panel announced by the Government began accepting applications for licences for the drug from senior clinicians on Wednesday after cannabis U-turn.
item.body: An expert panel announced by the Government began accepting applications for licences for the drug from senior clinicians on Wednesday after cannabis U-turn. Prescriptions for medicinal cannabis in exceptional cases could be available within a fortnight. An expert panel announced by the Government amid an outcry over the case of severely epileptic boy Billy Caldwell began accepting applications for licences for the drug from senior clinicians on Wednesday. The Home Office announced the panel will make "swift" recommendations to ministers, who will then sign off on applications within two to four weeks. If given approval, doctors can then start writing prescriptions for their patient, while ministers decide whether to remove cannabis's banned status as a medicine. Doctors will have to show there is an "exceptional clinical need" and no other medicine would be suitable for their patient in order to convince the panel. They would also have to accept "full responsibility for risks and liability", the Home Office said. The panel was announced during the controversy surrounding the department's confiscation of cannabis oil from Charlotte Caldwell as she attempted to bring it into the UK for her 12-year-old son. A 20-day emergency licence was granted for Billy, from County Tyrone in Northern Ireland, after he was admitted to hospital in a critical condition having suffered multiple seizures. The panel is a temporary measure while Chief Medical Officer Professor Dame Sally Davies carries out a review into whether cannabis should be made available for therapeutic use. The Government also announced it would review how much the NHS must pay for a licence, which currently stands at £3,655. The Home Office said patients and their families will not be asked to contribute to the cost. The panel will begin meeting this week and will be led by Northern Ireland's Chief Medical Officer Dr Michael McBride. Policing minister Nick Hurd said the panel will ensure patients get the best treatment based on medical evidence. "Clinicians must be at the heart of the process to provide the reassurance that prescribing unlicensed and potentially untested products is in the best interests of the patient," he added.
item.title: Medical cannabis prescriptions could be available in two weeks after Billy Caldwell outcry
item.ogtitle: Medical cannabis prescriptions could be available in two weeks

item.description: A South Yorkshire dancer is among the 12 new contestants poised to join the ITV2 dating show Love Island.
item.body: A South Yorkshire dancer is among the 12 new contestants poised to join the ITV2 dating show Love Island. Savanna Darnell, 22, of Dinnington, will join the show alongside Ellie Jones - the former flame of star Jack Fincham, 25-year-old hairdresser Grace Wardle from London, as well as make-up artist Kazimir Crossley, 23, also from London. They will be accompanied by Charlie Williams, 24, a tanning shop assistant from Bath. Savanna landed a role in Thriller Live, a globe-trotting West End musical which celebrates the career of Michael Jackson at the age of 20 on the day she graduated from college. Aged three to 16, Savanna danced with SDK, in Dinnington, and then progressed to the Midland Academy of Dance and Drama, in Nottingham. On the day she graduated from the academy Savanna found out she had landed the prestigious role.

item.body:
North Wales smashed its own record for the hottest day of the year today as temperatures again soared above 30 degrees.
 
Porthmadog was the hottest place in the UK this afternoon as temperatures rose to a baking 31.9 degrees - beating the 30.6 degrees recorded in the town on Tuesday afternoon.
 
The reading yesterday was the hottest UK temperature recorded in 2018, before narrowly being beaten by Rostherne in Cheshire later in the day, which recorded a temperature of 30.7 degrees.
 
Forecasters are predicting the record could be broken again within the next 24 hours as temperatures continue soaring.
 
The record for hottest June day in Wales is 33.7C.
 
  The hottest UK temperature of the year has been recorded in North Wales  
 
A spokesman for the Met Office said: “The temperature seen at Porthmadog will not necessarily be the highest today but it is the record so far this year.”
 
The hot weather continued to cause problems in the region, with the A543 between Pentrefoelas and Bylchau remaining closed after the road surface melted in the extreme heat on Tuesday.
 
Road closed due to hot weather 
Council staff have remained on the scene attempting to fix the damaged road surface, but have said it could be days before the road reopens.
 
And police warned homeowners to keep their properties secure after seeing a spate of burglaries in Wrexham.
 
Offences over the last five days happened on Bryn Estyn Road, Wyndham Gardens, Chestnut Avenue, Cefndre, Colwyn Road, Mile Barn Road and Ruabon Road.
 
  Road closed after it MELTS in North Wales summer heatwave  
 
Sergeant Simon Williams said: “This type of crime is often opportunistic, where burglars take advantage of unlocked doors and insecure windows which are being left open due to the recent warm weather.
 
“We are asking residents to be extra vigilant and to report any suspicious activity.
 
“Officers are investigating these incidents and I would ask people to engage with our community teams and to secure their property when left unattended.
 
“There are simple steps you can take; ensure that your doors and windows are locked securely, don’t leave valuables and cash out on display and mark property.
 
“Don’t leave your home unlocked, even if you are only in your garden.”
 
  This North Wales village was sunniest place in Wales - and there's more to come  
 
RNLI chiefs also issued a warning for people to be careful if going into the water during the hot spell.
 
The Met Office’s heat-health watch alert is currently at level two, meaning social and healthcare services are at the ready to reduce harm from a potential heatwave.
 
It is set to remain, dry and hot through to the weekend in North Wales.
 
 Share your views about this story using the comment section below.
item.title: North Wales town hottest place in UK for second day running

item.description: These shocking images capture the early stages of the raging fire that has swept across Saddleworth Moor for the last three days.
item.body: These shocking images capture the early stages of the raging fire that has swept across Saddleworth Moor for the last three days. READ MORE: Calderdale Council issue warning over moorland firesHolidaymaker Kate MacRae, 48, snapped the scene from a plane when she spotted huge palls of smoke rising into the sky from her seat. She was returning to Manchester Airport from a trip to the Shetlands via Aberdeen when she spotted the clouds of smoke as the plane was descending to land. Kate described the scene as ‘looking like a volcano.’ She said: “It was about 7pm on Monday when I was coming in to land that I noticed the smoke. “It looked like a volcano with the plumes of smoke rising up into the air. I took some pictures on my phone through the plane window and thought nothing more about it. “It was only when I saw the blaze on the telly last night I realised I had photographed the early stages of it. “From a distance, it looked like a huge volcanic eruption.” More than 30 homes have been evacuated as the fire service struggle to take hold of the huge flames. The blaze has been declared a “major incident” with the Army is on standby to step in if needed. The fire began on Sunday night, reignited on Monday during the hot weather and then spread throughout Tuesday, fanned by evening winds. Thirty-four homes in Carrbrook, near Stalybridge, Gtr Mancs., were evacuated but there are no reported injuries. Smoke has completely engulfed the village, with locals advised to keep windows closed and for asthmatics to continue taking their medication. The fire, which measures 3.7 miles (6km) across the tinder-dry hills, has been raging for days despite efforts to halt it. Great Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) confirmed the blaze was spreading and said crews have recommended “offensive firefighting”. Assistant Chief Fire Officer Leon Parkes said there are ten fire engines and 50 firefighters at the scene facing “enormous” challenges against the blaze which has “pockets” occurring in different areas. Smoke and flames can still be seen for miles but Mr Parkes said crews had “quelled the risk” to homes at risk from the flames. He said it had not been established what might have caused the fire. Fire crews used a helicopter to drop water on the fire on Tuesday, and Mr Parkes said the blaze had “presented some real challenges to the fire and rescue service in terms of access”. Firefighter Ricky Case, who has been out on the hills, said: “It’s just the sheer vastness of it. It’s one of the biggest ones I’ve been on in a long time. The logistics of it all, trying to get water to the locations where we need it.” GMFRS group manager for Tameside, Phil Nelson, added: “Crews are still tackling this difficult fire and are working hard to contain the blaze and prevent further fire spread. “Firefighters are faced with very difficult circumstances, intense heat and are working on challenging terrain. “Our main considerations are for crew welfare. It is physically draining working at this incident and it is vital that our firefighters have regular breaks and that relief crews are available to take over.” On Tuesday night, GMP said more than 30 homes in Carr Rise, Carr Lane and Calico Crescent were being evacuated due to the proximity of the flames. Calico Crescent resident Dee Blanchard, 28, stayed at home through the night to help save animals and pets on the street, including cats and hedgehogs. She is a former military police officer who served in Afghanistan and Iraq but admitted she’s now starting to get nervous. “We went outside and there was just this fire crackling literally on the hill behind the house. The smoke was acrid and thick. We could hardly see,” she said.

item.description: Fire crews are battling against water supplies to extinguish the fire
item.body: Four fire engines raced to the scene of a scrap yard which had caught alight and will continue burning until after midnight due to low water supplies. Firefighters have been battling the blaze since the early evening with large plumes of black smoke travelling across the countryside. Residents in Harlow could see the thick smoke and believed it was coming from the Potter Street area of thew town, but it has been confirmed the fire began in a scrap yard in the Foster Street area towards the east. Four fire crews were dispatched, two from Harlow and one each from Old Harlow and Epping, to battle the blaze at around 6:31pm today (Wednesday, June 27). When firefighters arrived they were met with a stack of timber, a diesel tank and scrap cars alight, and rushed to remove gas cylinders away from the embers. They have worked hard to stop the fire from spreading to other units in the same area but have also been battling low water supplies. Crews have had to create a shuttle where they are travelling to the fire hydrant to collect the much-needed water and bring it back to the scene. Richard Green, Station Manager, speaking at the scene at around 8.30pm, said "It's been unfortunate a large fire started in a scrap yard and fire crews have been working really hard in the hot weather and conditions, but we have got the fire surrounded. "It will be burning for another three to four hours due to poor water supplies and we're struggling but we are dealing with it. "We're doing the best we can the crews have done really well at stopping it spreading from other areas and other properties. "We will carry out an investigation and it is cool enough to walk on." The station manager continued: "We have a water shuttle which is travelling backwards and forwards to fill up and supply the engine. "There is no obstruction to the road way. If people are concerned of the smoke, they should pass with their windows closed." Smoke was travelling across the fields in the surrounding areas. Firefighters remain at the scene dealing with the fire but say they are making progress as the smoke has turned white. The Control Room at Essex County Fire and Rescue received dozens of emergency calls reporting the fire as it could be seen from as far as the M11. An ECFRS statement says: "Firefighters were called to a fire at a scrap yard in North Weald Bassett, Epping at 6.31pm. "The Control Room received dozens of 999 calls reporting the fire as lots of smoke could be seen from the M11. "When fire crews arrived they reported the fire involved a number of scrap cars, cylinders and a diesel tank." It is not yet known what started the fire at the scrap yard but the crews will conduct an investigation when it is safe to do so.

item.body:
Joe Jackson, the patriarch of the famous Jackson family of entertainers, has died at the age of 89.
 
The father of Michael, Janet and their eight siblings had been battling cancer for some time before his death.
 
He took his family from poverty in Gary, Indiana, and launched a musical dynasty.
 
Five of his boys - Michael, Jermaine, Marlon, Tito and Jackie - made the clan an instant sensation with the arrival of the Jackson 5 in 1969.
 
 
Over the following decades, millions would listen to recordings by the Jacksons, and Michael would become one of the most popular entertainers in history before his death in 2009.
 
Joe Jackson had suffered poor health in recent years, suffering a stroke and three heart attacks in 2015.
 
Jackson’s wife Katherine, who he lived separately from, is reported to have been at his side at the time of his death.
 
 Michael Jackson's doctor, Conrad Murray, freed from jail 
 
Jackson began working on the music careers of his children in the 1960s when he put together the Jackson 5 group in the family’s home city of Gary, Indiana.
 
As the group’s manager, he oversaw their rigorous rehearsals and booked performances for them at talent shows and small venues.
 
 
He helped secured the band’s first record deal and they went on to enjoy success with hits ABC, I Want You Back and Rockin’ Robin among many others.
 
He was known for ruling his children with an iron fist, with Michael later in life making allegations that his father had been physically and emotionally abusive to him and his siblings.
 
 Tributes for Lois Lane actress Margot Kidder who has died aged 69 
 
Jackson’s children also enjoyed successful solo careers. His son Michael’s album Thriller is the world’s best-selling album with estimated sales of more than 60 million copies.
 
 
Jackson is survived by his wife Katherine, sons Jackie, Tito, Jermaine, Marlon and Randy and daughters Rebbie, La Toya and Janet, as well as Joh’Vonnie Jackson, who was from an extramarital affair of his.
 
The Rev Jesse Jackson tweeted a tribute, writing: “Joe Jackson, brother beloved, patriarch & creator of one of the most talented American musical dynasties.
 
“We will remember him as long as his family’s music plays. Offering prayers and condolences to the Jackson family. £RIP £NeverCanSayGoodbye £JoeJackson.”

Here's a name you should make a note of because you're going to be hearing A LOT more of it – Holly Nadine McCoubrey.
 
 The Shankill native recorded a cover version of Ed Sheeran's hit Perfect last month and it's beyond brilliant. 
 
 It caps a great week for the 20-year-old after she passed her first year exams in children's nursing at Queen's University. 
 
Clearly a VERY talented young lady!
 
 Have a wee listen to Holly's cover above and if you like what you hear head over to her Facebook page to listen to some of her other recordings.

A man, 20, was found stabbed to death in Edmonton in north London.
Metropolitan Police officers were called to the scene at 6.33pm today after reports of a fight involving men armed with baseball bats.
Upon arrival they found a man suffering from serious stab wounds and the air ambulance was flown to the scene.
The victim was pronounced dead at the scene at 7.20pm.
There are two additional crime scenes nearby and enquiries are underway to find the man's next of kin.
No arrests have been made, Scotland Yard said in a statement.

item.body:
The 50 Best Places to Work in the North East can today be named after a competition organised by The Journal.
 
The initiative is part of ncjMedia’s Invest in the North East campaign, a key aim of which is to make the North East a better place in which to live and work.
 
Companies from around the region submitted entries, with organisations scoring each entry on factors including policies for staff development, community involvement, perks and bonuses, and looking after workers’ physical and mental health.
 
Gateshead College has topped the list with judges praising its inspirational leadership, commitment to staff development and the role it plays in its community.
 
 
 
Best Places to Work awards 
 
 
Four Newcastle firms - Ubisoft Reflections, Home Group, Muckle LLP and Ubisoft CRC - make up the top five, while a number of smaller firms have punched above their weight to make the list.

item.body:
Gateshead College, Ubisoft Reflections, O Communications and Muckle LLP were the big winners at the North East’s first celebration of the region’s Best Places to Work.
 
The college was ranked top place to work in the region and also took the prize for the best non-profit organisation in an initiative run by The Journal as part of our Invest in the North East campaign.
 
Newcastle computer game company Ubisoft Reflections was named best large company while fellow city firms Muckle LLP and O Communications took the medium and small business prizes.
 
 
There were also prizes for Hoults Ltd, operators of the Hoults Yard business village in Newcastle’s east end, which took the prize for best perk for giving staff free driving lessons, discounts at on-site hairdresses, regular social events and even pole-dancing classes.
 
Northumberland chipboard manufacturer Egger UK won the prize for community involvement for a range of projects in Hexham, support for the Northumbria Blood Bikes charity and for providing an annual bursary to put a young person through university.
 
 
 
 
The best office award went to Newcastle’s NBS, which has turned the city’s old post office on St Nicholas Street into much-admired offices for its fast-growing global base.
 
And the event was rounded off with Gateshead College principal Judith Doyle - described by Ofsted as a “dynamic and inspirational” leader - winning the prize for best boss.
 
The event, which was sponsored by Northern Gas & Power with support from Muckle LLP and Penshaw View Training, was held at the Biscuit Factory in Newcastle before a sell-out audience.
 
 
 
 
Journal business editor Graeme Whitfield, who introduced the event, said: “We started the Best Places to Work initiative because we wanted to recognise companies in the region that looked after their staff as well as the bottom line.
 
“Making this region the best place to work is one of the key aims of our Invest in the North East campaign, and it is no accident that companies that go the extra mile for their workforce tend to also do well in business too.
 
 
“Reading the entries to Best Places to Work made me proud to be from the North East - not to say a little jealous that I don’t work at some of these places. They sound great!”
 
Entries for Best Places to Work came in from around the region, with judges scoring companies on factors such as staff development, perks and bonuses, community involvement and staff engagement.

item.description: A team of police officers have been recognised for their work to help ensure a Sheffield burglar was jailed for six years.
item.body: Chief Supt Stuart Barton presented six officers with Good Work Minute certificates for helping secure the conviction Paul Cooper who broke into a property in the Hunters Bar area on June 3. Cooper, 36, of Norfolk Park road, was arrested and charged with burglary. He pleaded guilty to the offence and was jailed for a total of six years at Sheffield Crown Court on Monday, June 25. TPS Scott Szymczak said: “As a result of the excellent description and actions of the witness at the scene officers were able to locate Cooper trying to make his escape with the stolen goods. "Cooper was caught in the act and thanks to the hard work of the officers and PCSOs involved along with the officer in charge of the investigation - Det ConLamb and the Sheffield CID team - he was quickly charged and remanded for the offence preventing any further offending. "South Yorkshire Police recognise the impact that burglary has on its victims and are working hard to bring offenders to justice with significant sentences such as this”. The actions of the officers and PCSO’s who attended the incident, arrested Cooper and identified key evidence were today recognised by Chief Supt Barton who awarded them a Good Work Minute for their actions.
item.title: Officers rewarded for helping put Sheffield burglar behind bars

item.description: A woman discovered her husband and son had drowned while magnet fishing when she rang her spouse's phone and the police answered, an inquest heard
item.body: A woman discovered her husband and son had drowned while magnet fishing when she rang her spouse's phone and the police answered, an inquest heard. Angela Andrews was concerned that husband Martin Andrews and son Jack had not returned from their fishing trip when she called. Father and son Martin, 43, and Jack, 19, are believed to have been trawling the bottom of the canal with a magnet when they lost their lives on June 16. The pair had gone out early that morning and Angela had expected them home at lunchtime. At an inquest today (Tues), coroner Paul Dennison said: “The police were alerted by a member of the public after a number of personal items were found on the canal bank. “The police arrived at the scene at the Cooper Bridge area where a mobile phone was ringing. “An officer answered and spoke to Mr Andrew's wife who was calling because she was concerned of their whereabouts. “She said they had gone out magnet fishing at 6.30am and she was expecting them home at around lunchtime.” Speaking prior to the inquest, Angela Andrews, 44, described her husband and son as “heroes”. However, she explained her tragic last words to the pair were “don’t go into the water.” Martin and Jack Andrews were found by police divers at 7pm on June 16, after a local dog walker spotted their belongings on the canal bank at Cooper Bridge near Brighouse. Angela said: ''I feel like I've been robbed of my future. "I told them that when I went to see them at the chapel of rest, like how, how can you just leave us like that. ''I never got to kiss him goodbye that morning cos I was in the shower when they left. "And my last words were 'stay safe, be careful - don't go in the water'. “But somehow - they did end up in the water. Their bodies were found a few hours later. ''They were together, in the bottom of the lock. Round each other, so it looked like, one had fallen in, the other had gone after. “They're both heroes to me, they've tried to save each other.'' Martin and Jack had only recently discovered magnet fishing - and had bonded over collecting many old an unusual items. Angela said: ''It came about because my brother came across a bottle - an old glass bottle - in the river and really wanted to find out about it, and he thought I wonder what else we could find. “So we got the magnets, magnet fishing, and it properly brought them together.'' Angela said she is taking comfort from the community - including efforts to fundraise for their funerals. She said: ''The support has been overwhelming. I’ve not opened any cards yet. For the reason that they started arriving on Father's day.'' She said every Father's Day will be a reminder of the tragedy - but also a reminder of the bond between Martin and Jack - who died doing something they loved. She added: "That's one of the things making me feel strong. I know they were together. And they had hours of fun before the tragedy happened.'' The police summoned the underwater search team who retrieved the fully submerged bodies of Martin and Jack at 7pm. They were tragically pronounced dead at the scene by paramedics at 7.15pm. Coroner Peter Merchant confirmed the cause of death was drowning after a post-mortem was carried out on the bodies by Dr Lisa Barker on June 19.
item.title: Fishing pair described as 'heroes' as inquest into canal tragedy opens
item.ogtitle: Fishing pair described as 'heroes' as inquest into canal tragedy opens

item.description: The innocent 20-year-old victim suffered two broken hips in the horrific incident which turned out to be a case of mistaken identity.
item.body: The innocent 20-year-old victim suffered two broken hips in the horrific incident which turned out to be a case of mistaken identity. Police have released shocking CCTV footage showing the moment a biker was mown down by a car in a targeted attack. The 20-year-old victim suffered two broken hips and other fractures in the horrific incident. The Manchester Evening News reports how a court has now heard that the innocent Suzuki rider who was hit was mistaken for someone else by his thug attackers. After knocking the biker over using a red Citroen in Burnage, Manchester, Louis Lomas, 22, and his 21-year-old passenger Callum Gervis approached the man on the ground. However, after realising he wasn’t the person they intended to hit, they dragged him on to the pavement and then ran from the scene. Both men have been jailed at Manchester Crown Court for the sickening attack. Lomas, of Burnage, has been sentenced to three years and four months for Grievous Bodily Harm (GBH)and has been disqualified from driving. Gervis of Moston, Manchester, has been sentenced to two years and four months for GBH and possession of Class B drugs. The attack took place just before 1am on January 7th this year. The victim was taken to hospital for treatment and later that evening, Lomas and Gervis were arrested. Detective Constable Steve Lowton, of Manchester Police, said: “Lomas and Gervis mowed this man down, and the footage we’ve released shows how brutal this assault really was. “I cannot imagine how this man must have felt to be thrown from his bike, before being run over and abandoned on the pavement.
item.title: Shocking CCTV footage shows biker being mown down by a car in targeted attack

item.description: Police have released an e-fit image of a man they want to speak to after a robbery in Bradford.
item.body: Detectives are investigating the offence which took place on Paley Road at the junction with Hall Lane in the East Bowling area between 3.20pm and 3.40pm on Wednesday, June 13. Two men approached the 18-year-old victim and robbed him of his mobile phone and watch, it was reported. The first suspect was described to police as a mixed race Asian male, around 18-years-old, 6ft tall, of skinny build with short dark brown hair and brown eyes. He was wearing a red, white and blue hoody. The second suspect was described to officers as possibly being of mixed race, around 18-years-old, 6ft tall, of skinny build, with brown hair that was shorter than the other man's, and brown eyes. He was wearing dark clothing. Detective Constable Carrie Moore, of Bradford District CID, said: “This offence happened in broad daylight and we are hoping there will have been someone in the area who will have seen males matching the suspects’ descriptions or recognise the male pictured in the e-fit image. “Anyone with information can either pass it to detectives in Bradford District CID via 101, quoting crime reference 13180286865, or use the Live Chat facility on the West Yorkshire Police website.”

item.body:
Welsh politics is in the throes of an major changing of the guard.
 
 Andrew RT Davies is gone as leader of the Welsh Conservatives in the Assembly. 
 
We know that Carwyn Jones will have stood down as First Minister by the end of the year.
 
Ukip members will be balloted on who should lead its Assembly group.
 
Plaid Cymru may also have a leadership contest of its own.
 
This could mean that every party represented in the Assembly – with the exception of the Welsh Liberal Democrats, whose leader is not an AM – will go into the 2021 elections with a new leader.
 
Each of the parties faces vexing questions about its identity, its mission, and its strategy.
 
The changes also come at a time when the Assembly is braced for change. It has gained major new powers and there is the prospect of the number of AMs increasing.
 
It seems certain that, soon, none of the parties will be led by an AM who was there at the birth of the Assembly.
 
The Assembly has changed radically since Carwyn arrived 
 
First Minister Mr Jones was there on day one of the institution in 1999. He was present in the tumultuous first chapter when the future of the institution was far from assured.
 
He was in senior government positions as the Assembly gained law-making powers and passed landmark legislation. The Bridgend AM witnessed the construction of the Senedd and saw a body once derided as a talking shop evolve into a true legislature.
 
You could often sense a kinship between AMs of different parties who were part of that 1999 intake. It was as if they had been on the same ride down the rapids; until recently, one of the chief criticisms of the Assembly was it is just too cosy.
 
But the ambitious AMs who are now at the forefront of Welsh politics did not join an institution that looked in peril. They are in no doubt about the potential of the Assembly to shape the future of life in Wales and are ready to fight for control of the steering wheel and the accelerator.
 
One of the most common observations about how the Assembly has changed is that there is less of the palliness that defined early years. Party divisions are starker.
 
Welsh politics is a battle for power 
 
It should not be surprising that tribalism has increased. Politics in the Senedd is about a battle for power.
 
The Welsh Labour leadership contest is an opportunity for people to set out their vision for how the party’s values should be translated into policy. The rise of Jeremy Corbyn and the dominance of the left in the UK party means that old battles over the interpretation and application of socialism could be thrashed out once again.
 
Until the arrival of Mr Corbyn as UK leader, it was almost taken for granted that Welsh Labour would be to the left of party in Westminster. While Tony Blair championed partnerships with the private sector, many in Welsh Labour were proud of the “clear red water” which divided Wales and England when it came to policy priorities.
 
Wales was the land of free prescriptions; Westminster was where Labour introduced tuition fees.
 
But there is now the chance that Mr Corbyn and Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell will move into Downing St – and with that comes the possibility that Welsh Labour could find itself to the right of the UK party.
 
 
Finance Secretary Mark Drakeford, only joined the Assembly in 2011 but is the favourite to succeed Mr Jones. The Cardiff West AM represents a link between two very different eras of modern Labour history.
 
He was an early supporter of Mr Corbyn but was also by the side of First Minister Rhodri Morgan as a key aide and has sat at Mr Jones’ cabinet table.
 
His challenge, if he wins, will be to design authentically left of centre policies which do not dent growth or frighten business and thus provide a model for the UK party to follow.
 
However, the greatest change the next First Minister will face will come in March when the UK leaves the EU. European funding and participation in EU programmes shaped the first two decades of devolved government; the drama of Brexit will likely prove at least as influential on the next chapter of self-government in Wales.
 
It is uncertain whether the Conservatives will have a leadership contest. Preseli Pembrokeshire AM Paul Davies has been chosen as the group’s interim leader and been endorsed by Nick Ramsay, the Monmouth AM who was the runner-up in the 2011 contest.
 
 
Whoever emerges at the helm, he or she will be a stark contrast with Andrew RT Davies, a high-decibel campaigner who championed Brexit. The arrival of someone with whom Plaid Cymru AMs enjoy better instinctive chemistry would trigger speculation about the potential for a power-sharing pact that could give Wales its first non-Labour First Minister.
 
This would be a spectacular changing of the guard – and one that came close to happening in 2011, when a coalition between the Tories, Plaid and the Lib Dems seemed within touching distance.
 
 The period in which nominations for a Plaid leadership challenge can be made will close next week. Activists have called for both Carmarthen East and Dinefwr’s Adam Price and Anglesey’s Rhun ap Iorwerth to mount a challenge. 
 
 
A contest would force the party to confront key questions. Is it willing to work with the Conservatives when that party is in power in Westminster?
 
How explicit a goal should independence become? Do changes in Labour mean Plaid should avoid trying to outflank it on the left?
 
Meanwhile, Ukip is in a battle to secure a future for the party. The next leader of the group in the Assembly will not want to be the last person to hold that post.
 
He or she will have to ensure that by the time the next Assembly elections come round the party is known for more than splits and controversies. The next leader will have to scramble to win the trust of voters and convince them that Ukip can best defend their interests as the Brexit journey continues.
 
By 2021, the leader of every party will be able to agree on one thing: the Wales they are duty bound to serve has changed in ways nobody imagined in 1999.
item.title: The four leadership battles at the top of Wales' biggest political parties

item.description: The oak memorial cross will be placed in Witheridge Churchyard almost a century after John died in the village
item.body: Get Daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email Get daily updates pushed directly to you Subscribe to notifications A cross commemorating the life of John Roberts – who had 30 grandsons serving in the Great War – has been given the go-ahead. The oak memorial cross will be placed in Witheridge Churchyard almost a century after John died in the village, aged 90. John was born in Cruwys Morchard in 1829. He went to school, but never learned to read or write. By the age of 10, he was working full time as a farm boy, at Stickeridge Farm, just outside his home village. He married Mary Couch in Thelbridge in 1855 and they had 15 children, 12 sons and three daughters. When Mary died in 1900, John moved to Witheridge, to live with his son Thomas and his family at Newland Farm. John was 84 and had almost 100 grandchildren when the Great War broke out in 1914. He had more than 50 grandsons, at least 36 of whom were eligible to serve King and country. He lost seven of his grandsons in the war. Three were killed on the battlefields of the Western Front, three died from wounds sustained in action in France and Flanders and one died of heart disease in Mesopotamia. When he died just a few months after the war ended, he was a broken man. When his funeral took place on May 26, 1919, a special card produced for mourners, carrying the following verse, indicated the esteem in which he was held. Day after day we saw him fade, And quietly sink away; Yet often in our hearts we prayed That he might longer stay. He’s gone, the one we loved so well, To his eternal rest; He’s gone to Heaven we need not fear, To be forever blessed. He was buried in an unmarked grave in Witheridge Churchyard. His remarkable story disappeared into the shadows of history – until the publication in February this year of the book, History Maker , which tells the remarkable story of John and his 30 grandsons who went to war. John’s last resting place could not be traced because it was not issued with a grave number (the only way of identifying it on the local burial map). Consequently, the oak cross will make clear that he is buried within the churchyard. It is hoped that a small dedication ceremony can be performed when the cross is erected later this year. The verse on the funeral card published here has been kindly supplied by John and Margaret Chapman, of Norfolk. John is related to John Roberts’ youngest son, Sidney. The picture – from Witheridge Historical Archive – shows how John Roberts’ contribution to the war effort was reported 100 years ago.
item.title: Cross to commemorate man who had 30 grandsons in Great War gets go-ahead
